But our intervention, and I conclude, must be selective, reconciling strategy with emergency, supporting, both through subsidized credits and support for demand, a selective orientation towards environmentally more sustainable productions.

Thank you, Mr President. For future reference, if the future has a memory, we are witnessing a genetic mutation of that Parliament and that European Union, Mr President.
In 1985, you were well aware of this and contributed at that time to bringing the European homeland to life, against the disastrous illusion of the old Europe of homelands.
Today we are going in that direction every day.
Just yesterday and the day before, the Council evoked the old nationalist, non-Europeanist memory of Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals.
the Europe of Cadenao Calergi, but of Winston Churchill, of our names that give their name to our Parliament.

The Council's proposal, which undermines the good balance that was found at the time, and I am thinking of the great work done in this regard by my colleague Luigi Cocilovo, does not meet with our approval because it represents an objective step backwards.

It affects many aspects of work-life balance, the work-life relationship, the relationship between work and guarantees, and it is a choice that weakens workers' rights, which are also the rights of all of us, our children, and ordinary people.
And I wouldn't want this discussion to be mistaken for a union or corporate one, because I defend healthcare workers.
No, it's not like that. As a politician, I don't act on behalf of corporations or unions, I act on behalf of citizens.
I think of them when I make a choice, I think of their social rights which are fundamental to me in Europe.

I therefore do not believe that a good Europe is one that does not move forward while the world moves forward, or one that makes glaring errors of perspective, mistaking the weakening of protections for flexibility and freedom.
And this is all the more serious at a time when Europe is experiencing its worst crisis and sees no prospects for prosperity and growth.

If we do not understand, Mr President of the Council, representatives of the Council and the Commission, if we do not understand that at this moment millions of workers are at risk of losing their jobs and feel in a state of weakness and precariousness,

Mr President, honourable colleagues, we are facing an important compromise for Europe, even if the European Parliament has had to swallow a few bitter pills.
In substance, the text on renewables that emerged from the trialogue contains a clear definition of the objectives and, above all, of their mandatory nature.
The 2014 review clause is intended to be interpreted in a more flexible manner in order to achieve the remaining reduction target of 20%, and, if conditions permit, to push it up to 30% by 2020.

It should be emphasized that the most powerful and economically advantageous flexibility tool for Member States lies in national efficiency measures in the building, transport, and industrial sectors, as well as in the better use of electricity.
The mandatory ten percent target for biofuels must be qualified with efficiency requirements in the transformation processes, through the adoption of environmental and social sustainability criteria.
The use of biomass should be directed towards non-controversial areas, towards conversion technologies that are more effective than first and second generation biofuels.
The agreement reached by the Council and the will of the European Parliament send a positive message: one cannot tackle the serious economic crisis without changes in strategy.
Those who, like Berlusconi, mocked the three-way European directives, calling them a Don Quixotic plan, have been defeated.

The package that this Parliament is called upon to approve, despite the watering down due to the selfishness of the Member States, is moving in the direction of providing innovative responses to alleviate the impact of climate change.
If we do not act quickly, this problem will weigh more heavily on the European economy, but above all on the lives of European citizens.

It is undeniable that the Mediterranean diet is part of the historical and cultural heritage of our continent, just as its health-promoting principles are undeniable.

Mr. President, let's start with a concept that the Mediterranean diet confirms through numerous studies: it promotes the fight against obesity and cardiovascular diseases, and is generally very positive for human health in many aspects.

But the point here is not to claim that the Mediterranean diet should be imposed throughout the EU or to attempt to favor it over other dietary regimens that are better suited to different climates and regions outside the Mediterranean.
However, we have the task of protecting it, defining its content and characteristics, in order to defend it from imitations and external contaminations that could damage its image and value.
but therefore valued, like all other European cultural expressions that deserve to be defended and promoted globally.

The Italian Renaissance was a period of cultural and artistic rebirth in Italy, which lasted from the 14th to the 17th century. This period was characterized by a renewed interest in the classical culture of ancient Greece and Rome, as well as a significant development in the fields of art, literature, and science.

During this time, many famous artists, writers, and thinkers emerged, such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Dante Alighieri, Petrarch, and Boccaccio. They made significant contributions to the development of Western art, literature, and philosophy.

The Italian Renaissance was also marked by the emergence of powerful city-states, such as Florence, Venice, and Milan, which became centers of learning and culture. These city-states supported artists, writers, and thinkers, providing them with the resources and patronage necessary to create their masterpieces.

The Italian Renaissance had a profound impact on the development of Western civilization, influencing the arts, literature, and culture of Europe for centuries to come. Its legacy can still be seen today in the architecture, art, and literature of Italy and other European countries.

The crisis in the automotive sector has become a crisis for an entire industry, its suppliers, other related sectors, commercial networks, and services, and it offers a grim outlook in terms of employment.

I think that the dramatic decline in these latest enrollments for this month, which is said to be less than thirty-three less than twenty, etc., for some member countries, demonstrates that this is not a crisis of a technologically obsolete sector, nor does it originate within the sector or within this or that company due to managerial errors.
It is a systemic crisis and as such must be addressed urgently and decisively by the European institutions themselves.
Some remedies seem identified, but it is important how to implement them, with what resources and with what prospects for innovation.
Of course, demand must be supported; consumption is the only driver of recovery.

But, while this response of supporting consumption is being implemented, which is a medium-term response, I think we need to say that immediate credit support is necessary to resume production, pay for materials, and support employment, even in the face of a decline in orders and demand.
So the credit sector, but as we said, the how is important.
I too call here for a stronger role for Europe. It is important that the European institutions send a signal.

America is getting involved, some European countries are doing so, I also hope that my country moves from generic proposals to concrete initiatives, but I hope there will be stronger European action in the recovery plan and beyond the recovery plan.

And there is the other point that was raised, as Sacconi said, which I will reiterate: support should not be aid, worse still, a rescue that leaves everything as it is, but an incentive for competitive capacity.

Mr President, on reading the text of this document, one gets the impression that its author does not want an improvement but a deterioration in relations between the European Union and Russia.
If this is Europe's goal, then this document is excellent; if it is not, then it is terrible.
I believe it to be a very bad document.
How could we think of a future of new tensions with a country whose indispensability we recognize in our own interest?
In the next forty years, we will have to rely on the traditional energy resources that Russia is rich in.

Secondly, the manner and tone. In these pages, Europe speaks an imperial language, not the language of someone who respects their interlocutor.
This contradicts our own policy of good neighborliness and it would not be right to use it even against a small country, much less against a large country that rightly demands to be respected.

It is a matter of realism, first and foremost. The European Parliament is preparing to approve, I fear, a document written in the spirit of the Cold War, old, useless, harmful, counterproductive, precisely at a time when the new American president is coming to establish a new dialogue with Moscow.
With this approach, Europe cannot claim any leadership, and I hope that the Commission will not accept these recommendations.

of what happened inside Fiat here in Brussels.
Fiat has fabricated a story about a non-existent kidnapping of its executives by workers, with the sole aim of decapitating the union.

Thank you, Mr President. Dear colleagues, I would like to thank the blind presidency, the Commission, the Chairman of the Committee on Energy and Industry, Mr Nibler, and my fellow Members...
The rapporteurs of this energy package, the shadow rapporteurs, the Commission secretariat, with all its officials, for the collaboration and expertise demonstrated in this dossier.
We can and must all be proud of the result achieved. I am proud, thinking about the effort I made when I inherited the directive on the internal gas market, with problems that were not easy to solve.

I am pleased to have coincided my second experience as a European deputy with the final phase of this package, which I consider to be among the most important dossiers of this legislative term in favor of our European citizens, our voters.
The gas directive, which will come into force from the year 2011, brings significant innovations to the sector. It is important to highlight the achievement of the option as a major result.
ITO, which ensures the opening of markets and real progress towards a system that truly allows the European Union to speak with one voice on energy matters.
The OTI is the real innovation in this package and it is the one on which the European Parliament can be said to have achieved the best result.
The new gas directive gives a lot of importance to the gas authorities and the agency.
This directive legitimizes the authorities in their role, particularly in those countries where they must start their work from scratch.

Therefore, it is of fundamental importance to have designed the role and competences of these bodies, having given them broad powers, since it falls to the authorities to carry out the difficult task of controlling the common energy market.
Another element that was added during the trilogue phase is the exemption from the common rules of so-called closed systems, i.e., airports, hospitals, railway stations, industrial sites, etc.
Their particular peculiarities are subject to a more favorable regime, demonstrating the attention that the new directive pays to the needs of the European citizen.

In my opinion, it is the European citizen who will truly benefit from this directive, as they will have access to all information related to their bill through the use of smart meters, allowing them to evaluate the best offer on the market and choose their own supplier.

secondly, for reasons of convenience, because although it is true that it will take years to see the effects of this liberalization, it is nonetheless undeniable that the entry of new operators into the market will lead to a reduction in prices and more favorable market conditions for EU citizens.
Another important element is the recognition of European transmission network systems, which will ensure the security of gas supply to European citizens.
This also involves the reinforcement and creation of new infrastructure such as regasification plants and storage facilities, which will be the driving force behind the third package.
Therefore, a competitive market is required to ensure long-term investments and contracts from companies in the sector.
This is particularly true in the new member countries, where the creation of new infrastructure would also help to solve long-standing problems of dependence.
The protection of the most vulnerable consumers was taken into account, giving the national and regional authorities the possibility to guarantee their gas supply during the most critical moments.
The successful outcome of the gas directive and the entire energy package once again highlights the role of Europe and its institutions for European citizens.

Once again we find ourselves in this Chamber to defend a food, cultural and rural heritage stemming from a tradition that is centuries old, an invaluable heritage that the world envies us, which represents an enormous wealth for the economy and also for the identity of our Union.

A heritage that today risks finding itself in serious difficulty due to the Commission's and Council's desire to abolish the Coupage ban for the production of ros√© wines, a desire born under strong pressure.

pressure and that it will be ratified without the possibility of intervention by Parliament, the body that officially represents the millions of citizens, both producers and consumers, who will be affected by this initiative.

The Commission proposes to allow red wines to be produced simply by mixing red and white wines, as countries without our expertise and professionalism do, under the pretext of responding to international competition.
As the confirmee of the question, I emphasize that lowering the quality of our productions, the result of centuries of tradition and research, of extremely important investments, of passion,

and attention to detail is not the answer we need, especially in a time of economic crisis like this, when the average consumer is definitely more concerned about the price than about a label on the product.

To counterbalance this decision, it would be enough to find a name for the new product and inform consumers about the existence of two different types of ros√©, the varying quality of the products, and the importance of recognizing the work and efforts of industry professionals.
Who will pay for all this?

Does the Commission have any support programs in mind in this regard, or will producers still have to pay the price after being asked to fight low-cost competition with unequal weapons in already difficult times?
I hope that the Council Commission will make the right choice and, if necessary, completely revise this procedure.
Mr President, I should first like to greet the Chairman of the DTP party, Mr Ahmed Turk, who is here with us in the VIP gallery and is following the debate.

Dear Ahmed, know that we stand in solidarity with you, that we support the democratic struggle that your party is conducting in Turkey for the recognition of the fundamental rights of the Kurdish people.
We recognize DTP as an indispensable tool for promoting democracy in Turkey and therefore firmly condemn the police operations that...
Prime Minister Erdogan has ordered against you, imprisoning all three vice-presidents of the DTP, along with over three hundred militants and sympathizers.
The DTP's victory in the recent local elections demonstrates that the DTP party is a party with strong democratic popular support.

The European Parliament, in its resolutions, has called on Prime Minister Erdogan to engage in direct discussions with the DTP, but his response has been more repression, more police, more authoritarianism, more imprisonment.
Everyone knows that my parliamentary group and the left in Europe have so far supported Turkey's accession process to the European Union, while also supporting the reform process in that country.

However, I believe that in the last two years, and especially in recent months, Erdogan has shown another side: that of a leader compromised with the worst part of the Turkish army that simply wants to massacre the Kurds.
The reform process is practically dead, prisons are filling up with Kurds, it is Erdogan himself who is closing any prospect of Turkey's accession.
It is his, and his alone, the responsibility for what is happening in Euro-Turkish relations and for the growing perplexity of European public opinion towards Turkey.

I want to send a very strong political message to Erdogan: either he makes the search for a political and negotiated solution to the Kurdish issue a priority, which, let it be clear, goes through direct negotiations with the DTP, or we will be the ones to ask for the suspension of the accession negotiations with the European Union.

Turkey's path to EU membership goes through Diyarbakir and the DTP; otherwise, we, those who have supported the accession process here, will be the ones to call for a period of reflection that risks being definitive.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it really does seem that the thousands of deaths that have occurred so far due to asbestos, the tens of thousands of deaths that have occurred so far due to asbestos,

of people who are at risk of dying in the coming years due to previous exposure to asbestos, we know that the latency period can be as long as fifteen or even twenty years, which means absolutely nothing.
It seems that the Eternit trial that began in Turin is not continuing in relation to what happened in Casale Monferrato, where there is not a single family that has not suffered a bereavement.
Asbestos should have been effectively banned by the Member States by implementing the 1999 directive.

The states should have protected the exposed workers with all possible precautions, applying the 2003 directive, closing the plants, cleaning up the contaminated sites, compensating the victims and the populations.
This did not happen everywhere.
Little or nothing has been done.
I have already spoken about the Turin trial, where Swiss and Belgian bosses are on trial.
Everyone knew that little was being done, and it is primarily industry that is shirking its responsibilities and acting within the inertia of public authorities.
Examples of inertia are what happens, for instance, in Italy, in Brioni where asbestos has not been removed, in Porto Margherita, in Cengio where the dead are still being counted.
Today, the industry is asking the Commission to grant another derogation, already given for a limited time by the REACH regulation in 2006, for chrysotile asbestos fiber.

It is true that they have a limited application to low-voltage electrolysis plants and only in a few plants, but where industrialists claim that there is no alternative substitute, or else the plants will have to close.

A form of blackmail, but alternatives to this process have been found in Sweden, using technologies for asbestos-free membrane replacement for low voltage, and a similar solution has also been adopted for hydrogen production.
Why is this the case in some states and not in others?
Because, as in the long battle to ban PCBs, there have been countless omissions and hesitations to act, even endorsed by the European Commission's Enterprise DG.
Once again, a good example was not set.
The 1999 directive banning asbestos required that the review of this authorization be preceded by an opinion from the scientific committee on toxicology, which was never produced.
This is how the Commission respects the directives
not to mention the union which says it was not even consulted.
The European Parliament makes its own effort to keep up in compliance with others.

This resolution calls on the Commission to close a legislative gap by the year 2019 on banning second-hand products containing asbestos, roof tiles, aircraft parts and other items that should be disposed of permanently.
Specific dates are set, once again, for a strategy to ban all types of asbestos by 2015, but these were goals already written in 1999.
Ten years have passed and people have continued to die.
The GUE had claimed that one of the first initiatives of this legislative term was the establishment of a community fund to compensate victims and ad hoc funds for decontamination.
The request was specific to the Commission, which today instead cedes to the will of the multinationals.
Instead, we need to move on to concrete facts and commitments.
Only when these comply with the same requirements as this resolution, only then can we be understanding.
Today this intention is not evident, which is why we are voting against granting the derogation.

Thank you, Mr President, and I would like to convey to President Buzek the pride I feel at this moment in belonging to such an important institution as the European Parliament, which you preside over.
I believe that the sacrifices made in his country over the past twenty years and the fact that those twelve countries mentioned earlier are now represented at this Assembly strengthen Europe.
But I also want to convey my concern to you about hearing your program within your speech that should, and I hope it will be, strengthen this Parliament.
I hope that what he announced to us will come true.

I hope that the next President of the European Commission, certainly President Barroso, will listen to her for the strong words she has spoken, in order to ensure that this Parliament gives answers to more than...

550 million citizens who have voted for us in this Europe, who wanted us and who want and demand from this Parliament, from all of us, the answers that Europe has certainly attempted to give but has not fully succeeded in giving.
I place my hopes in this activity of yours and I am certain that with you we will be able to achieve the certainties that you yourself have promised us.
Mr President, Commissioner, honourable Members, it is not my intention, nor that of my group which supported and wanted this debate, to transfer Italian domestic politics to the European level.

The issue of freedom of information concerns us all, it concerns the European Union, which can and must regulate the matter at Community level, in order to counteract political and economic conditioning and to guarantee a genuine pluralism of information.

The Italian anomaly, where the Prime Minister is also the owner of some of the most important private networks, lies precisely in the existence of a dangerous intertwining of media, political, and economic powers.

This is precisely why we are calling for European regulatory intervention, an intervention that, far from being an act of anti-Italian sentiment, serves to protect the pluralism of information, preventing concentrations and conflicts of interest.

For this reason, today we are asking the Commission to intervene as soon as possible, as this Parliament has also requested in the past, to equip the European Union with common rules to protect the freedom of information for all European citizens.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I am aware that last September 30th the Commission presented a study on media pluralism indices in the Member States.
But in 2008, a report was voted on, with Marianne Micco as rapporteur, which called on the European Commission and the Member States to protect, and I quote verbatim, the multiplicity of...
of opinions on the media, to defend the pluralism of information, to guarantee all citizens of the European Union equal access to free and diversified information media.

And even earlier, in 2004, a report was voted on in Parliament, with Bogert Quack as rapporteur, on the risks of violation in the European Union of freedom of expression and information, which called on the Commission to present a communication on guaranteeing media pluralism in all Member States.
To date, the Commission has not yet provided clear answers to Parliament's requests.

You will notice, Commissioner, that I have not mentioned my country or my Prime Minister, but here, as a European citizen, I am asking you what the Commission intends to do at the European level to ensure that media pluralism is guaranteed in all Member States.
Thank you. Given that the vote that took place yesterday in the Environment Committee has been mentioned so many times,
I would like it to be evident instead that not everything can be reduced to a single extremist ideological position.

We have heard many varied positions from our colleagues, which are much more detailed, much more sensible, and therefore, being more in line with reality, I believe they are more capable of providing real answers.
Science as a totem does not exist, and when this mistake was made of identifying a problem in such an ideological way, no answers were given, but rather more problems were created.
Europe should be a master in dealing with disasters and not repeat the same mistakes, even if they are dressed up in different clothes and labels that seem ostensibly much more friendly.
I must point out that the emissions trading directive itself provides for the European Union's virtuous path to be evaluated by the Commission based on the outcomes of the conference.
We must go to the conference with strong positions and clear ideas, but also striving to fairly distribute the efforts.
Efforts among all industrialized countries, first and foremost, which must adopt equivalent emission reduction targets, but also not forgetting what our colleague Grostet so clearly pointed out,
Among developing countries, we cannot fail to make distinctions. There are truly developing countries, and there are countries that are now emerging economies, such as India, China, and Brazil.
these are countries that cannot fail to also assume their commitments.

I, on the other hand, strongly demand that if an agreement is not reached in Copenhagen, the European Union must continue to ensure the allocation of free allowances to the sectors at risk under Directive 2387 EC.

These are key points; we want the Kyoto Protocol itself to retain its environmental significance and, above all, we want to prevent the creation of a financial bubble at the expense of our European businesses.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, this is very important for two reasons: firstly, the research topic concerns the fight against neurodegenerative diseases; secondly, the joint research programming method.
We would obviously have preferred, and this was stated and the subject of our question, a more direct participation of Parliament in the pilot project.

If we are not to halt proceedings and must press ahead, we do, however, demand guarantees that our opinion will be taken into account in the Competitiveness Council's decision-making process and that a more certain legal basis is established for the future, allowing for full involvement of Parliament and greater ownership of this research matter.

Now we must intervene with adequate means and resources to prevent and eradicate such a widespread scourge as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other diseases that are destined to grow in the face of an aging population.
We ask that focus be placed on large-scale studies, both for diagnosis and for identifying treatments.

Research on biomarkers, on early diagnosis methods based on a multidisciplinary approach, the establishment of extensive databases, the search for curative drugs and appropriate care and service models seem to be fundamental.

I would like to make just one suggestion here: we should not overlook either the subjectivity of patients, which is too often excluded in this type of disease, or the involvement of patient and family associations.
From a methodological standpoint, we believe that joint research projects are very important because they address a fundamental need: that of concentrating efforts and resources.
to overcome those fragmentations, those duplications and thus be able to create a critical mass sufficient to produce appropriate results for this type of research.

If one considers that in other areas of the world, joint public and private efforts amount to investing tens of millions of euros, we realize how much we still have to do and how much we need to do, converging on projects.

shared, on strategic lines and programs shared between the States and Europe, and on common programs between public and private entities, without neglecting the international framework that puts us in contact with major scientific institutions at the international level.
What are the novelties of the Stockholm Programme compared to the Hague Programme? A fair balance between rights and security and legal protection in both criminal and civil matters.

Security is a right: not to be attacked in the workplace, to walk down the street without risking one's life, not to be subjected to violence because one is a woman, not to be exposed to acts of terrorism.
The states and Europe must ensure security.
But a security measure that undermines the guarantees of freedom is a measure that denies certainty to the law and is therefore a source of insecurity and barbarism.
Guantanamo.
Europe is the homeland of rights.
The Stockholm Programme defines them in great detail.

Today, a just balance must be struck between the discipline of crime suppression on the one hand, and the daily lives of citizens, their family, social, economic, work, and study relationships, all regulated by civil law and civil justice.
This is the Europe of the citizen.
and will be built within the states and in the community institutions.
European society is more united, and mobility is more intense than is commonly believed.
Taming is now a right.
The borders between states are not impermeable walls, they are networks through which society filters every day.
Stockholm provides the institutional framework for judicial cooperation and mutual recognition of European and national justice.
and Community law, European law, national and Community law, a European citizen, a European judge, the national judge and the Community judge.

European rules are dictated by Community regulations and the case law of European courts, but they also stem from the behavior of workers, businesses, students, national magistrates, and European networks among justice professionals.
bottom up, therefore, and this is a process from the bottom up. The Stockholm Programme aims to support it.
Parliament has made a great effort with this resolution, which I hope will be supported here by a broad, unified vote, which we have worked on intensively.
the Council will respectfully take this into account.
Lisbon is not yet in implementation, but it is there, very much present.
Let the Council be ambitious, Mr. Minister, and make the most of what we have developed here and the wealth of suggestions that emerge from it.
In the Committee on Budgetary Control, I must acknowledge the very important work carried out by the Committee, the excellent work of the rapporteur, and I must also mention the political cohesion.

This is because from the very beginning we wanted to send a very clear message: we intend to work with great rigor to ensure transparency, correctness, and legality in the management of public funds and, therefore, in the verification of budgets.
We have made some very significant progress with the Council, which initially did not want to respond.
I personally acknowledge this to the Swedish Presidency, which has always wanted to demonstrate that it operates towards transparency and correctness.
So we expect further progress from this point of view because obviously it is absolutely unacceptable, especially with the entry into force of the treaty.
Lisbon, that the Parliament does not have information and news precisely to verify the budget and public funds in the interest not only of the European Union but also of all European citizens.
Honorable President, we were in Ramallah when the news arrived that Europe had adopted a new decision on the Middle East peace process.
We saw the hopeful smiles of the Palestinian representatives.

It has been intense days of emotions and suffering, etched on the faces of children clinging to the window bars of their homes, on the Hebron road, the ghost road that cannot be crossed by any Palestinian.

The suffering of an eighty-five-year-old woman evicted from her occupied home, forced to sleep in the cold in a tent placed in the garden of what used to be her home, the suffering in the faces of those Palestinians who had built a farm with European funds, which was then destroyed by Israeli soldiers.
Israel has the right to be an independent state, but Palestinians also have the right to have a homeland, a state, and a passport.
The decision by the Council of Europe represents a significant step forward, but action is needed immediately.
The conflict between Israel and Palestine is the tip of the iceberg of a larger conflict.
On the last day of the visit, the Israeli authorities prevented us, the delegation from the European Parliament, from visiting the Gaza Strip.
I believe that on this issue, High Representative Baroness Ashton must intervene to make the protest of democratic Europe heard.

I thank President De Rossa, who led the delegation, and all the other members of the delegation because during the days we were in Palestine, the weak in Palestine were able to see and hear the face and words of a Europe that defends rights and wants and must do more.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Union is committed to the fight against terrorism in all its dimensions.
When it comes to combating terrorist crimes, it is essential to ensure that fundamental rights are fully respected and that the measures taken to combat terrorism are adequate and effective.

The rights of the defence and fundamental procedural guarantees must therefore be fully respected by the Union's institutions, even when they define lists of persons and identities, in this case linked to certain individuals.

Al Qaeda are subject to restrictive measures and it is equally essential that these measures are subject to appropriate democratic and parliamentary control, as rightly prescribed by the Treaty of Lisbon.

It is therefore clear that, as also stated by the Parliament's legal service, any measure of this type will have to follow the codecision procedure, allowing the representatives of European citizens to fully exercise their legislative and supervisory role.
Mr. President, I would like to avoid continuing to list the reasons for our disagreement with the Iranian government.
I will only take the liberty of pointing out, since it has not been mentioned here, the fact that one of the most serious violations of civil rights is that against young people.
The Iranian government, having signed the United Nations treaty in defense of children, continues to spend heavily on minors.
I would like, after this debate, for Baroness Ashton to commit to indicating a common line for all of Europe and the entire European Parliament.
European on the events in Iran and, on the other hand, that the interparliamentary commission with the government of Iran acknowledges that the course of action needs to be changed.

I participated with friends Scuria and Tattarella in the protest we had formulated against the Commission, which, despite issuing an official statement, declared its intention to go to Iran, having instead peremptorily requested the opportunity to meet with the opposition and engage in dialogue with it.

I would like the Commission to turn a new leaf from this moment and establish relations of aid, support, and dialogue with the opposition representatives who are in exile, not least Mrs. Miriam Raiavi who represents this reality.
This is what the European community should do rather than sanctions.

Colleagues, I am speaking to highlight the severity of the deindustrialization situations that are affecting several industrial centers in Sicily, particularly the automotive sector in Termini Imerese, part of the Fiat group, and the petrochemical sector in Gela, part of the Eni group.
Immerged in a situation worsened by competition from the low-wage system within some eurozone countries, it is also facing competition from Asia.
In view of the severe deindustrialization processes that are manifesting themselves in widespread areas of the Union, I believe that the time has come to reconsider the policy of non-intervention.
The European Commission has so far taken action and is beginning to implement a package of measures to support relevant and strategic European industries.
This appeal is primarily directed at the European Commission and Industry Commissioner Tajani.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the topic of good fiscal governance, while always being of great importance, has taken on even greater relevance and significance following the major economic and financial crisis of two years ago.
International leaders, the G20 and European leaders, have discussed this issue and continue to do so, particularly when addressing the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.
All of this is important, it is a sign of commitment and determination, but one must not delude oneself into thinking that an announcement is enough.
a serious and continuous policy is required.
there are still many problems.
It is still too easy to buy or set up a shell company to evade taxes.
Just take a look online, there are thousands of sites offering companies for purchase, even in European Union countries.
Often, an email with a scanned photocopy of the passport attached is all that is needed to open a company.
The practice of creating fictitious legal entities to evade taxation must be stopped.
The report I am presenting is based on the European Commission's communication on tax good governance of April 28, 2009.
The report aims to put forward concrete proposals and calls for a strong commitment from the European Commission and the Council to implement these proposals.
The fight against tax havens, tax evasion, and illicit capital flight must be considered a priority of the European Union.
Hence the principle of good governance, which is based on transparency, exchange of information, cross-border cooperation, and fair tax competition.
The point is that there is a need for ever greater cooperation and fiscal collaboration in the European Union.
The overall goal we must set for ourselves is to achieve an automatic exchange of information on a global and multilateral scale, starting, of course, with the European Union.
As my colleague Alvarez has already said, we must abolish bank secrecy altogether in European Union countries and put an end, without further delay, to the derogation regime.
a temporary measure that authorizes the application of a withholding tax at source, often evaded or underestimated, in place of the exchange of information.
I do not wish to dwell on the concrete proposals contained in the report.
I would like to emphasize that we still need to expand the scope of the 2003 Savings Directive, combat VAT fraud, and establish a public Union register in particular.
that takes into account individuals or companies that have set up companies or opened accounts in tax havens.

from the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. The European Union must also speak with a single voice internationally, advocating for the improvement of OECD regulations to achieve automatic exchange of information instead of exchange upon request.

Commissioner Kovacs, we also need to hear the other reports. We need a strong commitment from the Commission and we need these priorities to be emphasized to the new Commission at the moment of the handover.
We will hold the Council and the European Commission accountable for their work.
As the European Parliament, I thank my colleagues and especially the shadow rapporteurs for their contribution to this work, which I hope will be approved by Parliament.

I must admit that when we talk about fighting terrorism, discussing only intelligence and technology, I always have the impression that we are examining the issue inadequately, as if we wanted to cure a disease by focusing only on its symptoms and not on its causes.
Is it not time to address the problem of terrorism by targeting the heart of the issue, rather than merely focusing on its external phenomenology?

Tackling the heart of the problem means, for example, becoming aware that terrorism is also a direct manifestation of the inability or unwillingness of ethnic groups to integrate into the European cultural fabric.
I wonder and I ask this Parliament: do we want to discuss terrorism?
Let this Parliament then have the courage to engage in a political debate on the degree of integration of Muslims in Europe and their willingness to share Western values, rights, and freedoms.
In this regard, I have submitted a question to the Commission on the full veil to encourage this House to openly address the issue.
It seems that there is no will whatsoever to address the issue.
I wonder, and I ask you, honorable colleagues from all political groups, if not on these topics, on which other issues should the political voice of the peoples of Europe pronounce itself?

Mr President, honourable colleagues, concluding negotiations with Croatia by the year 2012 is a feasible objective, and the Svoboda report highlights in a balanced manner the progress made and the steps still to be taken.
Now it is the justice sector that still requires incisive reforms.
And it is not enough, in fact, to complete the necessary systemic reforms, approve new laws, and cooperate as necessary with the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.
I insist on the need to create a genuine legal culture and mentality in line with European standards.

The independence of the judiciary, central problem, the training, recruitment and career of magistrates, that is, the absence of various types of influence exerted by the government on judges, become crucial.
I appeal to the Commission to consider the need for decisive measures in this regard during the final phase of the negotiation.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Croatia's accession to the European Union reinforces the consolidation of a European identity, capable of expressing the common values of the new Europe, without obscuring, but rather integrating the specificities of its many different aspects.

The Republic of Croatia has made commendable efforts in adapting to the required parameters, particularly in combating organized crime through new anti-mafia measures, but it needs to make further efforts, especially in the judicial sector, before the negotiations of 2010 can be concluded.

Further progress can be made by the institutions of the Republic of Croatia to align with the provisions of the first protocol of the European Convention on Human Rights signed in Paris in 1952, by considering the restitution of nationalized property to its rightful owners.
Mr. President, once again recently in Italy there has been an environmental disaster in the Lambro River and the Po River.
Recently, the Court of Justice in Luxembourg condemned Italy for the danger to public health, for the illegal disposal of waste, and for its failure to control waste collection in the countryside.
And recent news of the increase in leukaemia in Taranto through ILVA, as well as the disposal of asbestos in schools in Crotone, as well as dioxin in Campania.
It's an ongoing environmental disaster.

I firmly ask the Commission what it intends to do to bring the Italian government into line with the standards of the European Union directives, with particular regard to the Court of Justice's ruling the other day.

The European Court of Justice has severely condemned Italy for its failure to manage waste in Campania, and the city of Naples has been exposed to public ridicule for many weeks and months around the world.

This debate is not ritualistic, but rather aims to be very concrete and to pose clear and precise questions about how many resources are needed, where to obtain them, and I hope, as does Parliament, that the answers will be equally clear and precise today and in the upcoming meetings on March 12 and 25.

We want to firmly tell the Commission and the Council that the European Union, which has raised the flag of the fight against atmospheric emissions and the climate challenge before the world, has a duty of consistency today if it does not want to lose credibility.
must do everything possible to ensure that these objectives are achieved.

We must be very clear that talking about a low-emission economy means a kind of Copernican revolution for the production system, it means changing many things, having clear priorities, political will, but above all adequate resources and tools.
We also know that this Copernican revolution is essential for our production system, European industry, to remain competitive.

I mean that in many countries, in many research centers, in many universities, the intelligences are ready, the capabilities are there, the will is there; it is now a matter of turning on this engine.
Everyone has to do it, said the Commissioner, said the Council, the Member States have to do it, the entrepreneurs, the private forces.
But I believe that the task of putting together this complex partnership is an indispensable one for the European Union.
In order to address the employment problem in a constructive manner, the key words in relation to the community are three: react, evolve, and protect.

React, that is, abandon the celebratory tones of Euro-propaganda, to address in a concrete way the problems that afflict EU citizens, ensuring a direct link between the world of training and the needs of the market and the territory, requalifying in young people the perception of manual professions.

evolve, that is, to make the EU 2020 strategy a positive synthesis between the demands of businesses and those of workers, in favor of a labor market in which the flexibility of contractual forms responds to the instability of market demand.

protect, that is, give work to those who have lost it, first and foremost to our citizens. The Member States must therefore assess immigration policies based on the real need for immigration, and with twenty-three million unemployed, we should consider the possibility of blocking extra-Community immigration for a few years.
I see no other way to protect our jobs and our social system.
What is needed is concreteness, courage and decentralization.

Mr President, this is an oral amendment to point 13, where it invites the Commission to verify, in the current situation, the possibility of providing humanitarian aid in line with the verified situation.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to emphasise once again the importance of the written declaration on corruption that I proposed together with four other Members of Parliament and that more than half of the European Parliament approved, in order to commit the Council and the Commission to truly effective legislation on corruption.

I returned on behalf of the Budget Control Committee from a visit to Greece and it is certain that one of the reasons for the Greek structural crisis is also due to the squandering of public money, a situation that also occurs in Italy.

riddled with corruption, as has become evident in recent days, corruption that primarily revolves around the illegal management of public funds, the relationship between a segment of the political class, a segment of entrepreneurs, and white-collar organized crime.

It is important that the European Parliament exerts all its pressure on the Commission and the Member States, that the Member States that do not comply are sanctioned, and that the European institutions responsible for controlling corruption and fighting organized crime are strengthened.
We know well that this difference is even more pronounced in the field of self-employment.
In fact, women are all too often forced to sacrifice their professional ambitions in the name of taking on the role and workload that comes with being fully dedicated to their family.

To solve this problem, I believe it is necessary to implement measures such as those contained in the directive we are discussing, but always keeping the family as our guiding star. Only this can give meaning and hope for success to these very measures.

Releasing women from the agonizing dilemma of choosing between the roles of mother, wife, and entrepreneur means making the burden of family work less onerous and addressing concrete problems through positive and specific measures to support families.
Putting the family at the center, otherwise any package of measures will be a disjointed set of interventions, ultimately useless.

Mr President, dear colleagues, Commissioner, today we find ourselves discussing organ transplantation, which undoubtedly represents one of the most positive aspects of progress in the healthcare sector.
but on the other hand, it opens up a whole series of problems regarding the rights of the donor and the patient that need to be addressed on an ethical, social, legal, and economic level.

It is a matter of activating a virtuous path that addresses the serious imbalance between the need for and quantity of available organs, without undermining the principle of free and voluntary donation.
all forms of commercialization and illegal trafficking, ensuring the quality and safety of organs intended for transplantation, with measures that balance confidentiality with traceability.

It goes without saying that in a context of cross-border exchanges and significant differences between the transplant systems adopted in the various Member States, these objectives can only be achieved by promoting coordination and cooperation.
In this regard, I believe it would be very important to establish a European database and adopt common quality and safety standards.
We must be careful, however, not to introduce unnecessary forms of rigidity or create additional bureaucratic burdens that compromise what is currently being done correctly and effectively.
Here, it would not only be contrary to our objectives, but also contrary to our objectives.
Mr President, I thank the rapporteur for the excellent work done on the European Union's accession to the Convention on Human Rights, which has been approved by the European Commission.

This is a benefit for European citizens, because it will result in a new external court to the European Union to ensure that the rights of European citizens are always respected by the European Union and its member states.

By virtue of the principle of democracy, the European Union and its Member States must always have the right to defend themselves. For this reason, I believe it is essential that every nation that adheres to the Convention should have a judge who explains the context of each appeal.

It is important that the European Parliament has an informal body for the purpose of coordinating the exchange of information between the Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council, and it is also important that the Parliament is consulted and involved in the negotiation process.
I would also add that European citizens have the right to understand the mechanisms of this accession, just as they have the right to know what their rights are.

Therefore, I believe it is essential that the Council of Europe and the European Union consider developing guidelines, with a clear explanation of all the effects and implications that membership will entail.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, 170 measures in five years, numbers that are too ambitious for a programme lacking a real connotation, especially on certain issues.

The program on migration, beyond the official documents, shows an embarrassing weakness. What is the point of promising to strengthen bodies and agencies if there is then a lack of a political strategy?

A truly useful strategy must be based on several key points: combating illegal immigration along the southern border, sharing the burden of combating illegal immigration among all European states, a policy of agreements with third countries, and above all, recognizing that immigration is not a resource during a crisis.
On the Parliament's homepage we read that more than twenty percent of young people in Europe are unemployed.
In a continent with twenty-five million unemployed people, the Commissioner for Home Affairs says that the issue of migration must be based on solidarity.

Instead, we must think concretely and realistically. Today, the priority is to give work to our citizens; everything else is empty rhetoric that does not help either the integration of immigrants or our people.
Mr President, I apologise, but I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Presidency to intervene so that the links to...
that the flights between Strasbourg and European capitals are direct and do not continue to cause inconvenience to those who have to take three or four planes to get to Strasbourg.
Please take appropriate action.

The national financial challenges of recent months and years, the new Lisbon Treaty with its new tasks, and the challenge we have set ourselves with Europe 2020 require the mobilisation of new and substantial financial resources.
The paradox we are also witnessing in this debate is that, at the present time, both the Commission and the Council appear to be silent, unable to make a choice and determine decisions.
But we know that if we want to get out of the difficult economic and social phase, if we want to tackle the major challenges of the environment, the development of cohesion policy and the
In agriculture in the coming years, we need to invest more in Europe and in Europe's function, and therefore in Europe's essential function, namely its budget.
For this reason, we must not be afraid to discuss, even in a phase of financial resource constraints, investing more in resources.
having the strength and ability to develop a debate and a comparison that links the issue of more resources to the issue of higher quality and greater flexibility in their use.
And this is the challenge that lies ahead of us.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European Parliament is called upon, as we know, to express its final opinion on food information for consumers.
It should be immediately noted that this was an objectively laborious, lengthy, and controversial legislative process that could not be shortened.

The aim is indeed to harmonise Community law on foodstuffs through regulations designed to make information transparent to consumers, avoiding misleading choices that could potentially harm their health.

The report by Mr Sommer, who deserves credit for his efforts to summarise multiple requirements, therefore aims to remedy the controversial and diverse information systems currently in place in the countries of the Union.

It is no coincidence that national regulations to date differ in the designations of the nature of foods placed on sale, generating a different system from country to country, and also fueling unfair competition to the detriment of potential consumers.
An attempt was thus made, based on the proposal of the European Commission, to give new life to the current legislation, involving both the food industry and consumers.
At the same time, the report commits the European food industry to clarify mandatory indications and the presentation of food and nutritional values.

In a globalized market, the European Union could not avoid adapting and innovating its food legislation to better protect the trade of food products, safeguarding them from increasingly invasive and fierce international competition.

It is not new that one hears more often about the perversity of food products than about the standardization of names and indications that often do not meet the food requirements but are still marketed as beneficial for human health.
Commissioner, we have requested this oral question and a parliamentary resolution to clarify with the Commission that
Within the framework of the Stockholm Programme, it is very important to build a widespread European legal culture throughout our territory.

I would like to say straight away that this is important, but also that, in view of the communication that the Commission will have to produce for us on future pilot projects, as has been said, we would like to clarify a few concepts.
First of all, that the consultations begin early, the Parliament's consultations in the meantime, and that they reach the initial phase, when the idea starts to be drawn up.
We are involved in these future projects because we do not get too late when the projects are already formulated quite completely.
And I say this because we have some fundamental observations to make.
Considering that the national magistrate, the lawyer of the individual States, is today a decisive pawn in the construction of Europe.
because, by interpreting national rights in a European context, it provides the conditions for resolving conflicts and regulating the daily lives of citizens.
And thus it establishes European citizenship, thus establishing a European sensibility among all those who live in these territories so that they can see their children with their own eyes.
The advantages that the introduction of European elements into all the rights of the States, and therefore especially of Community law, brings to the citizens' lives.
they offer real advantages for addressing a range of problems that would otherwise remain unresolved.
What I mean by this is that we would like to turn the approach on its head.
For example, we would not agree that these projects are Erasmus-style, because the number of judges and lawyers involved in Erasmus-style projects would be.
very low, as it must be, due to the high costs of physical mobility in this field, and therefore not very relevant in the overall context of the magistracies.
But the most important issue concerns the term familiarization courses that we introduced in our document.

Judges are not schoolchildren sitting in a classroom who can be lectured to; they are mature, highly professional individuals with little time available for this, who cannot be easily moved, but they bring

knowledge in itself and must be stimulated so that this knowledge can be measured against the new problems of European law and European culture, creating conditions for exchange that are predominantly virtual rather than merely virtual.

physical, using technology, the network, and the various opportunities that can determine these exchanges, starting not so much from a general approach, but from individual cases, from the individual problems that magistrates and lawyers face.
that are new and that must stimulate professional growth for these legal professionals, within an actual incentive for them.
contribute to the autobiographical reflection on their experiences, on what they have learned, in order to respond to the challenges that Europe is presenting in positive terms.

As you can see, Mr President, Commissioner, we intend to introduce something new into the tradition of the courses that have been held up to now and which we believe have been ineffective for this purpose.

We need to know how much funding he has available and what kind. We have doubts about the idea, as written in the communication, of a central European institution governing this process because we are in favor of a grassroots movement rather than centralization.
This is a new approach.

What we mean, however, is that if a European mentality is not formed among magistrates and lawyers, who in this way offer their services to justice and to the citizens who demand it, we will not make Europe.
So this is not just an important card for European justice, it is an important card for the entire development of European unity.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the proposal on the rights of passengers travelling by bus aims to improve and protect passengers, particularly those with disabilities or reduced mobility.
This is the first regulation on the rights of bus passengers and should guarantee passengers the same rights as in the rail and air sectors.
The position at second reading aims to establish a set of rights for passengers who choose to travel by bus.

I agree with the line taken by the rapporteur, Mr Cancian, whom I thank for the excellent work he has done, and I believe that the scope of the regulation should be amended to exclude regional services when they are integrated with urban and suburban services.
It would be right and proper to guarantee passengers' rights in the event of accidents, cancellations or delays in departure, as had already been decided at first reading by Parliament.

Equally important is the issue of information on passengers' rights. It would be useful, in fact, to provide passengers with information on connections with other modes of transport. This will also ensure dialogue between passenger transport services by bus and those by rail.

As for the disabled, people with reduced mobility must be guaranteed the utmost protection, and I would propose a twenty-four hour period instead of forty-eight for requesting assistance, as well as greater guarantees for compensation and replacement of mobility aids in the event of loss or damage.
Furthermore, taking into account the needs of passengers with reduced mobility, any architectural barriers should be removed and existing infrastructure should be improved to make them accessible.
This regulation aims to improve the competitiveness of the bus sector, promote intermodality, but above all to improve the travel conditions for passengers.

Mr President, I thank the rapporteur Mr Sterks who has done an excellent job on this report which deals with extending the free movement in the maritime sector for navigation within the European Union.
I share the rapporteur's aim of this directive, which is to exempt all maritime transport of goods within the European Union from unnecessary administrative formalities.

In fact, in order to have a European maritime space without borders, it is not only important that the various competent authorities cooperate satisfactorily, but also that the various simplification systems are applied at the same time.
This is necessary to ensure the smooth functioning of the entire European maritime space without borders, to make the transport of goods by sea more attractive and to be used in an optimal manner.

The harmonization of administrative procedures between Member States will allow for smoother navigation between the various ports of the European Union and will boost maritime freight traffic, which currently accounts for less than 10% of the total.
To date, navigation continues to be hindered by the administrative formalities imposed on it.
Electronic systems should therefore come into operation as quickly as possible, because it would allow for a faster data exchange system.

Moreover, interoperability is important for achieving real administrative simplification. In fact, the transmission of information via email is not entirely efficient and is useless if the information systems are not technically interoperable.
As for language, I believe that the use of a common language would certainly benefit European maritime navigation.
This would make communication faster, causing less confusion and fewer administrative delays.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would first of all like to offer my special congratulations to our rapporteur, Mr Kramer, because we all know that we have truly achieved a result that sometimes seemed unexpected.
I would like to remind you that this directive, this dossier, was considered to be at real risk of being subject to a conciliation procedure.
So we have also heard from the Commissioner's words that it is evident to everyone that we are dealing with a job that was complex and required a lot of time.
Suffice it to think of a directive from 1996 and that this work brings us to the fifth and most important amendment of the industrial emissions directive.
I believe that these few data points alone tell us everything about the shortcomings and even the flaws of this legislation.

I would like to remind you that a directive that is difficult to implement, with nine Member States affected by infringement procedures, has a scope that is so extensive that it is sometimes inappropriate.

We must not hide the fact that this has involved considerable efforts, required sacrifices from all the institutions involved, from all the political groups, from all the national delegations, and has often placed us before truly difficult choices.
But I am here this evening to say with conviction that in my opinion we have achieved the best possible result to protect competition, the environment, and European industrial and employment policy.
On the one hand, we have a directive that imposes common obligations on all Member States, but on the other hand, we also have a directive that allows for the necessary flexibility.

Here, I truly hope that the results of this recast will be, in the short term, also the reduction of administrative burdens and, in the medium term, the improvement of environmental performance and the strengthening of the European industry.
Mr President, I would like to highlight the situation in which the crisis places us before a reality to which for too long we have not given the importance it deserves.
namely the instability in Central Asia, which unfortunately is growing, while the hopes for democracy and economic progress, at least in some of these countries, prove to be particularly fragile.

Kyrgyzstan has suffered in the past month from extremely harsh confrontations that will leave, at least in the immediate future, a legacy of interethnic hatreds that will make the stabilization of the country even more difficult than it was before.
The task of the international community and the European Union in particular, as has already been said, is to assist Kyrgyzstan in every possible way in three areas.
emergency supplies and the reconstruction of destroyed homes. Secondly, through long-term economic aid, as far as the European Union is concerned, within the framework of its

strategy for Central Asia and the instruments implemented in this context, through political support to back the process of returning to constitutional legality and the establishment of a genuine rule of law.
The constitutional referendum, which has been in crisis since June 28, under obviously very difficult conditions, can be considered a first step on the road to a return to constitutional order.

The electoral process on June 28, among other things, received a positive assessment from the OSCE observation mission, which obviously took into account the special conditions under which the referendum was held.
Kyrgyzstan's new constitutional order will be more oriented towards a parliamentary system than towards a presidential system.
This will perhaps allow for a better consideration of the country's diverse ethnic composition and the need to gather consensus from the various components of such a fragmented and diverse country.
The European Union and Crisis are bound by a partnership and cooperation agreement that provides for regular meetings of a parliamentary cooperation committee.
It is our hope that our interparliamentary relations can resume as soon as possible with the participation of a credible, democratically elected Parliament.
In the immediate term, the crisis, as already mentioned, needs stability and our political and economic help. Let's try not to be stingy with either.

Mr President, honourable colleagues of the European Council, who no one has voted for, today we also have a rotating Presidency in the hands of a government that has been dismissed by its own citizens.

This alone would be enough to understand why Europe is experiencing a profound crisis, an Europe that has now become a political paradox in the hands of a political elite with which citizens no longer identify.
The program of the Belgian non-Presidency speaks of structural reforms, employment growth, financial stability and competitiveness and the chosen instrument would be the EU 2020 strategy.
The current crisis, however, should push Europe towards very different ingredients from those that led to failure.

A general rethinking is necessary, because the crisis is not a reflection of decline, but rather the death certificate of the European social model that Euro-propaganda would instead like to administer as a cure.
Today Europe is an immense building that is collapsing in on itself under the weight of democracy, centralism, and obstacles to free enterprise.
To emerge from the crisis, Europe must change its vocabulary: more decentralization, less bureaucracy, more practicality and attention to the real problems of citizens.
Everything else will only inevitably accelerate the decline.
Mr President, thank you, I apologise. I would like to emphasise in this speech how the progressive erosion of European farmers' incomes at the expense of increasing
The profit margins of the agro-industrial chain are creating a worrying economic marginalization of those working in the agricultural sector, resulting in the abandonment of the same activities.
A change of direction is therefore necessary, which the European Commission itself acknowledges, and which the report under consideration this morning in the Chamber
The approval of the Chamber this morning, to which I want to express my support, emphasizes with ample reasons and suggestions of a legislative and behavioral nature.
It is indeed necessary to fight against global speculation on raw materials and ensure the security of supplies.

Moreover, better price transparency must be ensured, which not only gives justice and dignity to farmers, but also corrects the strong imbalances in bargaining power and prevents abuses among the different operators.
Agriculture must reaffirm itself as a sector of economic and social stability and regain its power in the European Union's commercial context.
Mobilism and myopia: this is the diagnosis of the malaise affecting Europe 27 today.

The reason for the unrest is that in Italy, one in four young people is unemployed, and in the Eurozone, there are sixteen million unemployed people. This is also because the noise of the Euro-propaganda of recent months has not been followed by any concretely effective action.

The shortcoming lies in the fact that Europe, in indicating the way out of the crisis, has not only represented the usual recipe, but has completely lost sight of the most self-contained territorial dimension of the economic and social cohesion policy.

Only by placing the territory at the center of political action, only by respecting its unique cultural vocations, can European policies for development and employment be revitalized, drawing nourishment from the natural energies that each geographical area expresses: districts, small and medium-sized enterprises, and craftsmanship.
To solve the employment problem, we must first think small, invest in local entities, and prioritize subsidiarity while protecting a heritage made up of linguistic and cultural diversity.
If the needle of the European compass does not guide its policy towards the territory, the shipwreck of the Europroject is a certainty.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, in the construction of a Europe of rights, freedom of information, pluralism of information, and independence of information hold a central place.

Did Commissioner Sir, Commissioner Madam, notice that there is a country in the European Union, which, incidentally, was a founding member of the European Union with the Treaty of Rome, where there is none?
There is pluralism of information, where a Prime Minister directly or indirectly controls public and private television and the press.
What kind of democratic electoral competition can there be in a country where a Prime Minister or a political party controls the media?
What kind of democracy can exist in a country where they want to pass a law within days that does not allow journalists to publish judicial news?
Anything but Watergate, anything but a press that is the regime's guardian, a lapdog. What kind of democratic country is it where the internet is to be brought under control?
What democratic country is it where those who oppose the prevailing thought are sidelined and the free expression of thought and dissent are not guaranteed?

We are not describing the Sudan of Bocassa or the Romania of Ceausescu and the Italy of Berlusconi, where unfortunately this happens also because the European Commission does not have the courage to express an autonomous and free position with respect to the Member States.
The completion of the internal market for postal services by the end of this year is an important step, but it would be

It would be appropriate for the Commission to conduct an impact assessment, as some colleagues before me have pointed out, of the opening up of the postal market, in order to better understand the needs of citizens.

How does the Commission intend to protect the right of European citizens living in hard-to-reach areas such as mountainous or rural regions to receive their mail regularly, and what instruments does the Commission intend to adopt to ensure this happens?
I also believe that this directive, which already exists, should not be used to justify the problem of social dumping.
It is the Member States that must implement the directive and they have all the tools to do so.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, today's debate on readmission agreements cannot avoid the now thorny issue concerning the agreement between the European Union and Libya.
We know that part of the agreement is focused on combating illegal immigration.
We are concerned because, to date, the Commission has told us very little about this, despite the fact that the Lisbon Treaty requires the Commission to inform Parliament promptly.
As is well known, Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention on Human Rights, nor has it demonstrated any behavior in line with international law to date.

I think of the case of Eritrean immigrants detained inhumanely in the Libyan center of Brak, or the closure of UNHCR offices, but I think above all of what happened last week when a Libyan Republic speedboat opened fire.

against an Italian fishing boat from the Marina di Mazzara del Vallo present in international waters, with the justification of the presence on board of illegal immigrants, a very serious justification that makes us think that the agreement signed between Libya and Italy that

it also provides for the deportation of immigrants to Libya without provisions for the right to request asylum and individual case-by-case examination of individual situations, and also includes the possibility of using firearms to stop immigrants.

Since part of the agreement is secret in this case as well, I wonder whether the Commission is aware of the content, if it does not consider it necessary, in this specific case, to ask for explanations.
The Commission has proposed the possibility for Libyan authorities to open fire on boats if there is a suspicion of transporting irregular immigrants.

From an economic standpoint, it is beneficial for Europe to deepen trade relations with neighboring countries experiencing strong growth. However, the EU has always pursued, at least in words, a trade policy towards third countries, taking into account social and humanitarian aspects.
We must therefore assert these clauses with firm determination in relation to Turkey, a country that is becoming increasingly Islamicized, where the condition of women is gradually deteriorating.
women killed in 2009 in cases of domestic violence, a country where Christians live in fear of attacks by Islamic extremists, just remember the brutal murder of Monsignor Padovanese.

In the report, Parliament encourages Turkey to take a leading role in promoting fair and open trade. One thing is certain: we must be concerned about the political leadership role that Turkey is trying to carve out for itself in the Arab world.

the friendship that Turkey is cultivating with Iran and terrorist groups like Hamas. However, if trade policy is to be, so be it, but this must never become the Trojan horse to facilitate Turkey's entry into Europe.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, Commissioner, this measure aims to strengthen and rationalise the European Union's pharmacovigilance system.
These are the ambitious objectives set out in the McEwan reports, which amend Regulation No 726 and Directive 2001/83, respectively.
Thanks to close and efficient collaboration between the Council and the European Parliament and the relevant parliamentary committees.
we are discussing today a proposal aimed at improving the Community pharmacovigilance system and refining the European Union's extensive and decades-long work in this field.

Simplification, transparency and rationalisation can be considered key points of these two reports, which propose measures aimed at ensuring the best possible protection of public health, based on standards harmonised throughout Europe.

Reference is made to a wide range of interventions ranging from a better definition of the roles and responsibilities of the main national and supranational stakeholders to a new and more consciously active involvement of the patient.

recognizes a fundamental role in the system, in strengthening the transparency of information regarding the safety of medicinal products, in simplifying the activities of communication, registration and evaluation of alleged negative side effects.
The current pharmacovigilance system needs to be improved, also thanks to closer collaboration at European, national and regional levels.
Effective participation at all three levels will indeed ensure a fruitful exchange of information regarding adverse drug reactions.
The new pharmacovigilance system will be able to ensure a high level of shared and secure information for the benefit of patients, national authorities and healthcare professionals.
Mr President, it is precisely these days that the men who waged the war have been here in Brussels.

Many representatives of municipalities and regions have discussed how to address the serious problems that affect the life of our cities, the old and new needs that concern workers, families, and small and large production companies.
The economic crisis that has hit our societies has made it harder and more difficult for everyone to provide adequate responses to a new serious social issue.
In this context, I believe that everyone has understood that the cohesion policy has, on many occasions, been the only concrete tool available to the territories to attempt to provide answers.
Therefore, we can say that the cohesion policy has been, in recent years, an essential lever for the process of European integration for all regions.
We are now in the process of redefining this policy for the post-2000 era, so we are at a turning point.
For this reason, it is vital to avoid certain risks.
