The first fundamental one, that of its renationalization, would be a serious step backwards.

Then, in the construction of the funding budget, it is necessary to ensure an adequate allocation, both for the weaker entities and for the ability not to penalize the most competitive and advanced regions.
Finally, it is essential to simplify the procedures for those who have proven to be efficient and to make the ability to impose sanctions more binding for those who have not.
We expect the Commission to go in this direction.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the road towards a Europe tailored to women is still long and difficult.
The statistics speak for themselves: the global crisis has hit the job market hard, putting a strain on female employment, which decreased further by seven-tenths of a point in 2008.

Despite the provocations on the topic of equal opportunities and employment that periodically fill a Euro-propaganda in decline of consensus, to date no concrete measures have been adopted to guarantee women true fulfillment as workers and as mothers.
The Europe of the future needs to radically rethink its welfare model and not just periodically change the label.

It is therefore good that the directive aligns the maternity leave system in Europe, but it is inefficient to deal with the complementary and equally important paternity leave issue on the margins of this topic, in the same report.

The greater integration of women is not only a moral value, but also a strategic goal for the sustainability of the much-publicized European social model, which continues to fail to convince me due to the lack of results.
The rapporteur for the Development Committee, Mr Mitchell, asked me to replace him because he cannot be present today.
I thank him for the work he has done with his usual punctuality and for the quality of his proposals, which have received the favorable opinion, I would say unanimous, of the Development Committee.
Based on what I will say, but especially on what my colleague Michel has done so far, I am convinced that the report can be voted on with a large majority.
But I now come to the report.
In 2009, the European Commission presented a proposal to amend Regulation 1905/2006 of 18 December 2006 establishing a financing instrument for development cooperation.
With this proposal, the Commission had asked Parliament to approve an amendment that would allow non-governmental organizations to benefit from tax advantages when operating in developing countries.
proposal accepted by us.
But the cooperation and development regulation also contains the implementing rules for the European Union's development policy.
These rules stipulate that when the Commission is to allocate funding, it must follow the comitology procedures.

This means that Parliament has the power to examine these funding proposals and, in the event that the Commission exceeds its authority, Parliament can adopt resolutions to request the Commission to change the decisions in question.

Only from 2006 to the present day has the Parliament considered that in at least twelve cases the Commission had exceeded its implementing powers, but only in three of these cases has the Commission actually modified or withdrawn its proposed decision.
Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the Committee on Development proposed to apply the procedure for delegated acts provided for in Article 290 of the Lisbon Treaty.
The adoption of these procedures would mean that, at least in the strategic funding decisions that the European Commission must adopt, Parliament would have a more significant role.
In fact, according to the Lisbon Treaty, in certain well-defined cases, Parliament can delegate to the Commission the power to make strategic decisions.
In our opinion, the choice of countries to which the European Union should provide development aid

It is a choice that falls to the legislator to make. And so, which sectors should be given priority in funding: education, health, environmental protection, the capacity for good governance, the development of small businesses?
And how to ensure transparency in the management of development aid?
These are the choices and issues where the European Parliament should play a more important role than it has in the past.
This is where the legislator must provide precise guidance to the executive.
And this is precisely the direction in which, I believe, the demands of European citizens are ultimately heading.
I sincerely hope for the greatest possible consensus on this report by Mr. Mitchell.
to the rapporteur. On policy

An integrated maritime union must move beyond the stage of good intentions and give new impetus to a strategy that will act as a driver for growth and development in the European Union, making up for the enormous delays accumulated in the prevention of environmental disasters, the fight against climate change, and the battle against pollution.
This very morning our colleague Pirillo reminded Parliament of yet another catastrophic event that occurred in recent days in the city of Paola, in Calabria.

The Commission must demonstrate its commitment by not only using governance tools, but also implementing specific legislative measures, learning from past mistakes, which were often due to an overly sectoral approach.

There is full awareness that this process is very complex, but we are in the midst of a difficult and challenging endeavor that cannot tolerate lapses in attention and that requires adequate investment and

participatory governance mechanisms, both at the inter-institutional level and in international cooperation for regional basins, among which the Mediterranean stands out due to the complexity of its jurisdiction.
It will therefore be essential to understand the management of the Mediterranean basin as a common heritage to all the coastal states, based on the principle of the

On the other hand, the increasingly widespread practice of unilaterally declaring exclusive economic zones or similar in the Mediterranean Sea, besides not being in line with the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, would undermine the idea of effective and shared governance.

I would like to remind you in this regard that just a month ago this interpretation by Libya led to an actual armed assault on a European fishing boat, and it would be wrong to claim that this is purely an Italian-Libyan issue.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I thank Mrs Meissner for the report on the integrated maritime policy. I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen maritime transport and shipbuilding, protect coastal regions, and promote innovation and research activities.
Today, maritime transport plays a fundamental role in the commercial sector.
For this reason, cooperation should be encouraged between small and large ports that face the same sea basin and can facilitate a more fluid commercial exchange.
Moreover, to ensure intermodality, investment is needed in port and hinterland infrastructure, especially in ports that can be connected to European corridors.
Finally, I believe it is important not to overlook another issue, namely that of port security.

There needs to be a homogenization of all security measures within all European ports, in order to better protect maritime transport and prevent unfair competition at the expense of those ports that, in order to guarantee greater security, must incur higher expenses.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, thirty years ago Morocco denied for many years that there was a war with the Sahrawi people, today it is denying that there is a disproportionate repression against the same people.
Yet in Western Sahara there are dead and wounded from a population that claims only the right to live in freedom in their own land.
Morocco has essentially closed its borders to anyone who might witness these events.
No information and no deputies.
access was denied to a French MP and our colleague Meyer.
Europe watches passively
There is no sign in the Commission's communication that makes us subordinate to UN mediation, which continues to fail as it has for the past thirty years.
There is no statement from Mrs. Ashton, who is responsible for foreign policy.
a response is needed in the form of a parliamentary resolution.
Morocco must be countered by halting all initiatives on trade agreements, starting with the renewal of the fisheries agreements.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, my speech is not intended to be the usual eurosceptic rhetorical exercise, but an impulse for the EU to start focusing more on content than on packaging and to abandon propaganda in favour of concreteness.
Having failed with the Lisbon strategy, Europe has come up with a new EU slogan, "20-20-20", but in reality it has not provided any innovative solutions to employment problems.

The data confirms it: nine point six is the unemployment rate in Europe, twenty point two for youth unemployment. In Italy, the third largest net contributor to the EU budget, the situation for young people is even more dramatic, with twenty five point nine percent of young people without a job.

In the Europe I would like to see, there is no waste of resources in promotional campaigns, but rather efficient investments so that the educational offerings prepare professionals for sectors of the domestic market where there are concrete employment opportunities.
I conclude by reiterating the importance of investing in professional training, a symbol of the excellence of our regions.
The world of craftsmanship offers a potential for employment and a unique wealth of knowledge, to which the task of supporting the competitiveness of the European system must be entrusted.

Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President of the Council, the European will to set ambitious goals in view of the next conference on climate change is certainly a commitment to be pursued with tenacity and with the awareness that the results will condition the future of our planet.
But it is precisely for this reason, dear colleagues, that we must be realistic and more cautious in our expectations.

The international negotiations leading up to the Cancun conference, as far as we know, have not only failed to make appreciable progress towards a global agreement, but have also confirmed the distrust and resistance to the commitments made in Copenhagen.
China has already been mentioned, but I would like to mention it here as well.
China, for example, allows for an increase in its CO2 emissions of five billion tons by the year 2020, with consequences that could be offset.
and perhaps not even that, but an attempt at compensation with only a hundred percent reduction in European industrial emissions by the same year, by the year 2020.

This data not only renders the proposal of an unconditional 30% reduction, which we strongly oppose, unrealistic, but also leads many independent observers to hypothesize an increase, even a significant one, in global emissions by that date.

In this contradictory situation, it would be at the very least risky and even demagogic to hypothesize numbers and outline suggestive but unrealistic scenarios, where the unknowns inevitably reflect on the cost dimension.
The hope is that the European Union will bring a shared, realistic and sustainable proposal to Cancun, because an agreement that delivers concrete and perceptible results is always preferable to...

inevitably doomed to failure and increasingly discrediting, in the eyes of international public opinion, the efforts of governments on major environmental issues - this would indeed be a difficult damage to repair.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I have only one regret in this Chamber tonight that we are discussing the Sahrawi only because the Moroccans have invaded the tent city outside and the Yun, and this is a regret for democracy in this Parliament.
Parliament should have matured the will to discuss this issue that has been festering on international tables for thirty years.
This is the most significant political fact.
We were forced by acts of violence, not because we independently decided to ensure human rights.
Why is there a need for a referendum on self-determination if it is not about respecting human rights?

It is precisely because Morocco is our friend, because Morocco is the strong point of our relations, that we must demand with force and with all the consequent actions that there be an irrefutable will.
We must try to build the conditions so that the Minuso and Chiuso mission is not alone in building the conditions for a referendum that is constantly postponed.
We must try to use all the means at the disposal of the European Union to influence this event and to ensure that the referendum does justice to the thirty years of suffering of a people.
Mr President, apart from this issue, I wanted to raise a problem with the Presidency.
I believe that some people still do not fully understand the role of the European Parliament after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I am forced to raise a fundamental issue here. Transport Commissioner Callas repeatedly refuses to meet with the Sky and Space board to discuss the CESAR project, which is of interest to everyone from an economic, environmental, and safety perspective.
I call on the Presidency to summon Commissioner Callas to the chamber and to explain what programme he intends to pursue in this extremely sensitive and important sector for the European Parliament.

Colleagues, the report under discussion certainly contains some positive elements. The general approach is to simplify procedures and streamline bureaucratic steps for workers from third countries with a regular residence permit in the Member State.

However, just as a point of reflection, I would like to remind you that today in Europe tens of millions of citizens, including many young people, are without work due to the structural shortcomings of the European production system and the effects of a crisis that shows no sign of ending.

Even before taking care of citizens from third countries who reside in our countries, Europe should primarily focus on implementing economic, political, and social measures that help, first and foremost, our citizens to find or regain employment.
If Europe can provide jobs for its citizens, it will create solid social foundations to properly accommodate migratory flows from outside.
The watchword must be, first and foremost, to make Europe grow on its own legs and with its own strength.
our countries will then have the
Thank you, Mr. President. To date, access to employment is regulated only for certain specific categories of third-country nationals.
In fact, not everyone benefits from the general principle of equal treatment in access to employment.

In this context, the European Union must take action to ensure fair treatment for both third-country nationals who reside legally within the Member States and beneficiaries of refugee status or persons in need of international protection, as provided for in the Directive of 29 April 2003.

It is necessary to prevent a growing demand, for example, for seasonal workers just because they are paid less or because they have different, lower costs compared to a European citizen recruited for the same job.

For example, we must avoid the risk that many multinational companies will relocate their headquarters to countries like Morocco or Turkey and send their employees to work in European branches because it is cheaper.
For reasons of social justice, ensuring the same treatment of European citizens in terms of remuneration, working conditions, and social security is fundamental.
For this reason, I believe it is right that seasonal workers, posted workers, refugees and self-employed workers should be included in this directive.
drawing distinctions will become extremely dangerous.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, according to estimates by international organisations and police forces, human trafficking is now the second most profitable source of income for organised crime worldwide, after drug trafficking.
It is estimated that approximately thirty million people are victims of organ trafficking, prostitution, and forced labor.

This means that, first and foremost, the fight against this criminal phenomenon of vast proportions is a battle for the safety of our citizens, against illegal immigration, against crime that generates more crime.
Faced with a phenomenon of this magnitude, Europe must rightly implement drastic measures against those who exploit human beings in various forms.
Cooperation between member countries and police forces is necessary in the fight against this phenomenon, but above all, there must be certainty of punishment for traffickers.

They are exploited because in their countries of origin they do not find dignified living conditions, they live in poverty and despair and are ready to do anything to leave their land in search of the promise of a better life that will never materialize.

Europe, in addition to preventing crime and protecting victims of trafficking, must commit itself more and with greater diligence so that these people can find acceptable living conditions in their own countries.
Acceptable. Helping them at home must be the guiding principle of European political action so that our efforts are directed not only at repression but also at prevention.

The Italian Renaissance was a period of cultural and artistic rebirth in Italy, which lasted from the 14th to the 17th century. This period was characterized by a renewed interest in the classical culture of ancient Greece and Rome, as well as a significant development in the fields of art, literature, and science.

During this time, many famous artists, writers, and thinkers emerged, such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Dante Alighieri, Petrarch, and Boccaccio. They made significant contributions to the development of Western art, literature, and philosophy.

The Italian Renaissance was also marked by the emergence of powerful city-states, such as Florence, Venice, and Milan, which became centers of learning and culture. These city-states supported artists, writers, and thinkers, providing them with the resources and patronage necessary to create their masterpieces.

The Italian Renaissance had a profound impact on the development of Western civilization, influencing the arts, literature, and culture of Europe for centuries to come. Its legacy can still be seen today in the architecture, art, and literature of Italy and other European countries.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, as Vice-Chairman of the Development Committee, I am concerned with the problems of many countries, especially in the African region, where human rights are regularly violated, trampled upon, if not sometimes even forgotten.

I returned just last Sunday from an official mission to the Democratic Republic of Congo where, in addition to the usual institutional meetings, I wanted to meet with representatives of the NGOs operating in the country and visit some of the centers where they work.
I met the victims in a country where rape is conceived as a weapon of war, where armed groups continue to
repeatedly commit mass rapes and other systematic crimes against civilian society, especially against women, the elderly, and children.
I wanted to mention the example of the Democratic Republic of Congo because it was a recent experience of mine, as I was saying, very recent.
But the appeal I want to make is generally aimed at the need for a strong and continuous condemnation against the brutal violations of women's rights.
The international community must significantly increase funding for initiatives to protect women from rape and other forms of violence.
violence, including genital mutilation, is a serious violation of women's human rights and physical integrity.
The European Heritage Label is of fundamental importance for a continent that encompasses the majority of UNESCO sites and that
finally highlights those natural, archaeological, urban and cultural sites that have played an important role in the history, culture and integration of the European Union.
The approval of the label is an important step for the cohesion process of the Union and is also educational and formative for cultural dialogue.
It can also be noted that this choice bodes well for the new generations, who will increasingly have a shared vision of the European heritage that can be accumulated historically and culturally.

Thank you for the rapporteur's efforts and I extend my warmest congratulations for the negotiations conducted with the Commission and for the effective success of this initiative, so important for the future of preservation.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's, are a health priority for the European Union.
The disease in question has serious implications not only for the health of those who suffer from it,
But the costs that must be borne for direct and informal care are indeed high.
Alzheimer's disease, in fact, not only affects the people who are afflicted by it, but also involves all those who care for the patients themselves.

A European response to the problem is therefore necessary, a global coordination among the Member States, a synergy of concerted actions that primarily concern the scientific and research field and that address the problem.

strengthening prevention, diagnosis, and improvement of available treatments, including innovative ones, as well as the dissemination of information among states on the results achieved within them, thereby increasing the level of knowledge about the disease.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the situation that the Campania region, and in particular the city of Naples, has been experiencing for some time now is unfortunately known throughout the world, and the European Union has had to deal with the issue on several occasions.

Faced with this situation, now a paradoxical third-world scenario, I therefore ask the Commission what consequences Italy will face from the point of view of Community law and what economic sanctions will possibly be imposed on Italy if the waste crisis in the countryside does not find a definitive solution in the short term.

I also ask whether the Commission can provide detailed data on the European funds that have so far been managed by the Campania Region for the creation of an integrated waste collection and disposal system.
You see, Commissioner, usually when we talk about an emergency, we are talking about dramatic, extreme situations, which however find a solution within a reasonable timeframe.
When a so-called emergency lasts for more than 15 years, obviously something is not working.

In recent years, the Italian government has tried to do everything possible to resolve the long-standing issue of waste collection and disposal, but evidently, if the streets of Naples are now inundated with tons of waste,
tons of rubbish, the blame is mainly to be attributed to the local authorities in Campania and their total inability or lack of willingness to work towards finding a solution.

It is clear and absolutely beyond any doubt that the conditions in which Naples and Campania find themselves are due to the negligence that has characterized the management of the waste cycle by the municipality, provinces, and regions for many years.
If the separate collection of waste is not carried out properly, which is the first essential element of a functioning waste management plan, it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the Italian government had to send in the army, it happened a few weeks ago but also other times before, to replace hundreds of new recruits who suddenly and simultaneously fell ill, evidently it cannot be the fault of the central government.

If the emergency has hit Naples, while in the rest of Italy things are going very differently, for example in my region, Veneto, where separate collection has been carried out for years without problems and with a very high recycling rate, it means that the responsibilities for the emergency fall on

on Campania's politics and local administrators, and above all on the heavy collusion with the criminal underworld that has always sought and obtained enormous profits from the waste business, thanks to the infiltration of the Camorra into politics and local administrations.
After the lies of the Berlusconi government, which took office in 2008 by telling Italians that the waste problem had been solved, the European Union is doing the right thing.
to block funds to Italy until an environmentally friendly waste cycle is presented, based on waste recycling and composting.

And it is certainly not the plan presented by President Caldoro, which once again relies on uncontrolled landfills like those in Chiayano, Taverna del Re, and Terzigno, even within the Vesuvius National Park, nor on incinerators that produce death, cancer, or a veritable health emergency.
Public money in Campania, during the environmental emergency of these thirteen years, has consolidated criminal relationships between politics, both left and right, entrepreneurs, and the Camorra.

and environmental issues are resolved by criminalizing dissent, by criminalizing local communities, families, and the territory, as the Italian government has done by using the malganello to suppress those who defend nature and the territory.

International law defines a political refugee as a person who, fearing persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality, social membership, or political opinions, finds themselves outside the country of which they are a citizen.
Cesare Battisti is not a political persecuted person.

Despite the cover provided for years by France, we are talking about a multi-murdering criminal, perpetrator or instigator of four murders, who has hidden behind the pretext of political struggle to escape life imprisonment.
It is disgraceful for a great country like Brazil to deny the extradition of a unrepentant criminal by granting him the status of political refugee.
Italian authorities and, above all, the victims' families demand that this criminal be brought to justice.
Faced with President Lula's high-handedness in denying extradition, the EU cannot leave the Italian government alone.

Europe has and must use all the diplomatic tools at its disposal to ensure that Italy obtains the extradition of Battisti, even at the cost of threatening to suspend cooperation agreements with Brasilia.
provide concrete support to the Tunisian people and its transitional government, in order to relaunch a Euro-Mediterranean dialogue that has been seriously neglected in recent years.
The explosion of anger among the youth and the poor in the Maghreb and Egypt stems from the unequal distribution of wealth and the restrictions on the exercise of fundamental freedoms.

In North Africa, the flames of revolution are burning, demanding more democracy, more economy, more participation, more jobs, and with astonishment, they look at the old European continent, immobile and incapable of grasping the social transformations that have taken place in that area and of developing real policies of progress and peace.
Europe pays more attention to human rights and democracy, promotes more dialogue, more collaboration, and more real economic interventions.
Europe must open its doors and its heart to North Africa in order to make the Mediterranean a sea of peace.
Enough with the pushbacks of immigrants and the violent collaboration of countries like Libya, more investments, more hospitality and more aid, more Euro-Mediterranean policy.
History demands it.
The resolution approved today by a majority on the waste emergency in Campania is a very important signal.
The Campania emergency becomes a European emergency and it is a decision in favor of the citizens of Campania.
No to funds that simply consolidate corrupt politicians, unscrupulous entrepreneurs, and the Camorra; yes to European money if a credible plan is presented.

No to a waste management plan that is not environmentally friendly, no to uncontrolled landfills in national parks, no to incinerators that produce dioxin, but yes to recycling and environmentally compatible methods.
and it also says no to the criminalization of dissent by local communities, therefore yes to legality.

It is an important turning point, a warning to the Berlusconi government and to the regional government led by Caldoro, who until now have done nothing but talk and consolidate the cliques and the mafia bourgeoisie.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the problem of falsified medicines is having an increasingly widespread impact at international and Community level, both due to the increase in the number of cases and the improvement in their sophistication.
It is to these challenges that Mr. Mattias' report seeks to respond, the result of long and laborious negotiations.
The report to which we have expressed our support has defined a regulatory framework that, starting from more precise and detailed definitions, has taken into account
all the players, the moments and the resignations in the pharmaceutical supply chain, safety, traceability, obligations for the distribution chain, achieving a good compromise.
These are some of the aspects on which it is necessary to work in order to achieve the main objective of establishing stricter rules.
of counterfeit medicines, leading to a positive and more comprehensive regulatory framework, capable of safeguarding the health of citizens, protecting them from the risk of serious consequences.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, from Egypt, from the virtual square on Facebook to the real one, with millions of people demanding a fairer distribution of wealth, more justice, protesting against corruption.

From the transition of soldiers and armored vehicles, we must move on to real democracy, a new constitution, new elections, abolition of the death penalty, more humane prisons, social rights, and freedom.
It will be difficult.
Lurking are those who, in the name of an idea, think they can use any means.
We want to believe in the wonderful Egyptian people, who have never experienced democracy.

We want a secular democracy, with a clear separation between religious and political power, a democracy that integrates minorities and realizes true rights: public health, social security, and employment.
Europe should support this path, but invest resources that can foster genuine development in Egypt. No more dictatorships, no more misery, no more poverty.
Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that the issues related to the Mediterranean, with this measure, are entering an even more compelling phase compared to the actions we have taken.
I believe that the act we are enshrining today is much more important than the effects of the Community regulation, that of the year 2006.

I think this also addresses some limitations of that regulation, which, being unilateral, has left large sectors of the fishing industry often supporting the idea that yes, Europe does its part, but other coastal countries do not.
I think it is strategic for us to address the topic in this dimension and with these characteristics.
The work carried out by my colleague Rivellini, which I fully agree with, I believe deserves a formal expression of thanks in this context.
Nevertheless, I have the distinct feeling that the fact that we are unable to resolve this issue at first reading and will proceed to a second reading
above all on the interpretation of Article 28 of this regulation, raises a question. The Parliament, on this occasion, takes the Commission's side.

In other words, Parliament is essentially saying that it is good that these delegated acts are the responsibility of the Commission, but there is some resistance from the Council, and today's absence is also a significant one.
But this act ensures that the idea is ripe in Parliament that maintaining biodiversity, maintaining the fish stocks of this important sea is also the future of fishermen.
But having said that, I think that the phase we are facing must bring back to the fore the idea of codecision.
These delegated acts have a reason for being delegated and therefore conferred today to the Commission, but international agreements must maintain Parliament's role intact when these occur.
Mr President, Commissioner, I believe we have two problems here, one of method and one of substance.

The problem with the method is that we are using a procedural trick - for which we are grateful to Mr Fraga - in the form of an oral question, to discuss something that, following the Treaty of Lisbon, should instead be a right of this Parliament.
I think this practice must end, we cannot resort to a strategy to accompany a codecision process.
Codecision is such when it is cultivated in the phases in which it matures.
Today we are having this debate, the treaty is ending, it will go ahead and we will say yes or no in the end.
Well, this method needs to be reconverted.

On the substance, however, I just wanted to emphasize, as I agree with many things said by my colleagues, the measurement of the effects of the fisheries agreements, so that they are not just mere commercial agreements through which we go to buy cephalopods for one euro per kilogram in Mauritania.

These must be able to measure both sustainability but above all the impact on the economy of that country, understand how many employees are changing, understand what rate of innovation exists for artisanal fishing, understand the use of these resources.
It is not just a simple trade exchange, but a fisheries agreement, with all its implications.
Mr President, the vote in favour of Mr Rivasi's report is the result of an assessment of the management of H1N1 influenza.
2019-01, which is 2019-10, aims to establish general guidelines for conduct that will be valid in any future global health emergencies.
The report, following a long and positive phase of revision, makes cooperation, independence and transparency its main pillars.
It aspires to greater and better cooperation between the health authorities of the Member States and European institutions, so that a harmonised and common risk management can be established.
The objectives are to assess the strategies of the Member States regarding national influenza management plans, including vaccine stocks, the publication of names of...
all the experts consulted by the European health authorities and an efficient relationship of trust with the media responsible for disseminating public health messages.
That is why it received our favorable vote.

Mr President, Mr President, to date the recommendations adopted by the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean have been incorporated into Community legislation on a provisional basis, through the annual regulations on fishing opportunities.
These concern conservation measures, management, exploitation, control and marketing for fishery and aquaculture products in the Mediterranean.
The permanent nature of these recommendations, however, requires a more stable legal instrument for their incorporation into Community law.
It is therefore appropriate to incorporate the recommendations in question into a single legislative act to which future recommendations can be added.
Today we have done this and it will improve legal certainty, while also being an important step towards simplification.
At this point, the contracting parties of the CGMPM are obliged to ensure full implementation of the measures agreed upon upon the high-level meeting.

A timely transposition was therefore necessary in order to make these international measures directly applicable to natural or legal persons at Community level and to ensure legal certainty in the meantime.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I believe that the approval of my colleague Mrs Podimata's report represents a significant step forward for a more balanced, more advanced, stronger economic and fiscal policy in the European arena.

It is now clear to everyone that Europe, as a coordination of the twenty-seven countries, urgently needs to equip itself with economic and financial instruments capable of governing the economy rather than merely being governed by it.
For this reason, the proposal for a financial transaction tax has had a great echo, a great discussion, and a great deal of attention.

The fact that the majority of this Parliament voted for this rule is an important and significant event, because for the first time, things were not left to chance, and instead, a step forward was taken.
I hope that the Commission and the Council continue along this path.

Madam President, I welcome the reports on gender equality and female poverty in Europe and I am pleased that they have been discussed on this very day, which marks the 100th anniversary of International Women's Day.

Despite Directive 2002-73 on equal treatment between men and women as regards access to employment, vocational training and promotion, and working conditions, further efforts are still needed to achieve proper transposition.

Suffice it to say that, despite the level of female education having increased significantly in recent years and the number of female graduates now exceeding that of male graduates, women remain concentrated in traditionally female and often less remunerative sectors, and hold fewer positions of responsibility in all spheres of society.

The lack of access to care services for dependent persons such as children, disabled persons and the elderly, to adequate leave schemes and to flexible working arrangements prevents women from working.

I would like to conclude by remembering the women around the world who are fighting for the most basic rights, and I would like our Assembly to express solidarity with the Iranian feminist associations that are taking to the streets today, inviting women to demonstrate without the IJA.
Like all the colleagues who have spoken, we are finally talking again and I hope we will soon start taking action with specific choices in economic policy and common industrial policy.
Thanks to the Lange report, the excellent work done by my colleague, and the communication from President Tajani.

This choice means a few important things. First, the relaunch and recovery of the European economy and the maintenance of employment, as has been said, also lies, perhaps above all, in the recovery and support of the entire world.
manufacturing sector, from the most advanced sectors to the more traditional ones, because there is a frontier that can still be tackled there, and this was not as obvious until a short time ago.

Secondly, the recovery of industrial sectors in Europe also means that our competitiveness is not at stake in the finance and service sectors, but still here, and it is not too late to do so; we can aim for a European challenge to regain competitiveness with respect to the rest of the world in industrial sectors.

Thirdly, it has been said that the new industrial policy focuses on factors rather than sectors, focusing on the factors and tools that can truly promote new businesses and new capacity for resilience and updating.

So I believe it is important to underline them, as has been done, these new factors on which action must be taken, credit. We urge new initiatives, in addition to those already announced by the Commissioner on the subject of credit, raw materials, and energy costs.
innovation, research, the need to enhance Europe's capacity to transfer the results of research and innovation into businesses, new products and new production organization methods.

We have to enhance a very distinctive fabric in our Europe, and in some countries in particular, that of SMEs, that of the quality of companies, the quality of products, in short, the distinctiveness of industry in Europe.
and I believe that we should rediscover these manufacturing traditions, these manufacturing roots in many countries, in order to renew and change them.
Finally, the theme of the territory, which is very important.
European policies are successful if they intersect and find a territory capable of addressing them.
So thank you to Lange and we hope for excellent collaboration with the Commission to achieve concrete results in a short time.
Many milestones have been achieved, but some battles have yet to begin.
Today the urgency concerns women from other cultures living in Europe and the world, in contexts where it is difficult for them to claim minimum standards of dignity and humanity.

We cannot celebrate this festival without placing the issue of women in the Arab Muslim world at the center, otherwise we continue to ignore a problem that today concerns them but will soon become ours too.
We cannot ignore the emergency figures that grow year by year, even in Europe, in our cities, in the schools where our children grow up.
Cases of violence of all kinds that Muslim women suffer within their own families have been on the rise for some time.

This is why I have been asking for some time, and I ask again today, that Europe implement targeted policies against the spread of Islamic radicalism, forced marriages, honor killings, female genital mutilation, and domestic violence.
We, European women and men, must fight for those women who live in Europe, but not only there, who have no voice and are oppressed by the monster of Islamic integrationism.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution on Turkey because the constitutional reform that took place last December has been unanimously recognised as an important step taken by Turkey towards Europe.
Of course, there are still many steps to be taken, and I express my concern about the numerous arrests of journalists.

I emphasize that Turkey is the European Union's seventh largest trading partner and that the European Union is Turkey's main trading partner, and that trade, correctly interpreted for centuries, has fostered the interpenetration and peaceful understanding of peoples.

I therefore applaud the significant progress made in boosting connections between the European Union and Turkey, particularly those via the motorways of the sea that cross the northern Adriatic and northern Tyrrhenian Sea.
on which more than 250,000 trucks now move annually in both directions, in connection with an important rail truck-wagon-sub-wagon link from the Port to inland European destinations.
This has made it possible to eliminate a significant number of trucks on the road, and I hope that this trend will continue.
Mr President, with today's vote we have given a further boost to the definitive solution to this problem, but we have not voted for the best possible solution.

In fact, I would like to point out that the more than 300 amendments submitted to the report have been transformed into 38 compromise amendments, all of which have been adopted, and which aim to better define the priority sectors of the strategy, as well as the objectives of this strategy.

The Commission, with the permanent task force, will have to ensure the collection and dissemination of statistical data and best practices, and the Member States should appoint an official, hopefully of a high level within the Government, to act as a contact point for the implementation of the strategy.
But we could have been even more incisive and less hypocritical if in the report we had focused on the obligations and duties that the Roma community should still respect in the host countries.
This is my hope, that solutions will be found soon that allow for better coexistence of this community in all member states.
Lampedusa has been invaded by tens of thousands of North Africans that the island could never, ever accommodate.
Italy has been targeted for weeks by hundreds of clandestine balconies.
And if we do not all react together, if the EU does not react, the wave of migration of people on the run will continue.
The illegal immigrants who arrived in recent months must be sent home, there is no alternative.
But the Italian government, beyond a few words of solidarity, has been left alone to manage this biblical exodus of unpredictable dimensions. Where is Europe?
Up until now, Brussels has been conspicuously evasive, displaying a shameful behavior that my fellow citizens can no longer tolerate.
Europe has left Italy alone to face an unprecedented emergency.

However, Europe must not only help Italy with the repatriation of illegal immigrants, but also support the Italian government's efforts to prevent thousands and thousands of people from continuing to leave, especially from Tunisia.

A completely different discussion applies to the Libyan refugees, however, on whom Europe must stand by Italy in the operations of purification and logistical management, but above all must commit itself to ensuring that the refugees are hosted in all the member states.
The reception of those fleeing from war cannot fall solely on Italy.
It's time to stop the chatter.
The European Union, if it exists, must take action.
We cannot tolerate Italy being filled with illegal immigrants while France rejects them with disgraceful methods.
Illegal immigrants must be sent back home, while all member states must commit themselves, starting now, to welcoming Libyan refugees.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the issue of forecasting adequate financial resources to ensure the decommissioning processes of nuclear plants is a problem that has already been addressed by the
European Union legislation on nuclear safety is highly relevant today, in light of recent international events and the resulting decisions by EU governments on this matter.

Mr Marinescu's work, which we have supported, addresses the specific cases of certain countries which, at the time of their accession, took on particular obligations regarding the decommissioning of nuclear plants and which have received special support from the European Union for this very activity.
Beyond specific cases, it is imperative to establish effective verification and examination of nuclear power plants within the territory of the Union.
The number of reactors that are expected to be decommissioned in the near future within the Community territory appears to be high.
It will therefore be essential to ensure guarantee mechanisms, especially in these cases, for the allocation of adequate financial resources necessary to meet both ordinary and extraordinary needs.
I would also like to thank the rapporteur.
The report takes into account the recent changes in control and communication systems.
This also reveals a picture of great heterogeneity, particularly among the States in the reporting of irregularities and fraud.

The report repeatedly points out the oddity of the low levels of fraud and irregularities reported by various countries in relation to agricultural expenditure, structural funds, and pre-accession funds.
Here, it is truly necessary to clarify the statistical data that has been provided.
The situation is then exacerbated by the problem resulting from the ineffectiveness of the recoveries.
However, one thing is clear and confirms a long-term trend.

The fight for legality and transparency in the spending of European resources, such as combating tax evasion and avoidance, still cannot count on the full cooperation of the states and governments, along with the European institutions.

In this sense, I believe the suggestions made in a revision of the EU regulations on public procurement and the need for what I call a European public registry of beneficiaries of EU funds are appropriate.
I thank the speakers and also Commissioner Barnier for his great willingness to cooperate with Parliament.
We support the idea of an internal market capable of understanding and meeting social expectations and the implications that the social dimension entails.
It is not a utopia, it is realism and also modernity.

It is indeed this vision that makes the market itself stronger, because the sole economic element, economicism, in essence the reduction of the market to economicism, has demonstrated that all of this does not solve either the problems of growth or those of cohesion.
In short, it is a matter of fully and presently realizing the European idea of a social market economy.
This is present in today's texts.
There is recognition of social enterprises, cooperatives, their role, mutual societies, foundations, 10% of European businesses and a large part of our employment.
they are real companies, demonstrating economic pluralism and business pluralism.

They work with capital but not for capital, and they want to create jobs, welfare, quality, and social innovation, and demonstrate that these values must and can be part of the internal market in Europe.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, we are not convinced by Beijing's justification that the artist Ai Weiwei was arrested for economic crimes. We are not convinced that such harassment is being carried out against a free and dissident artist.
It is not convincing because this arrest is part of hundreds of arrests of opponents and the systematic repression of any dissent.

In the days when Arab uprisings are exploding, our thoughts go to the image of cruel violence in Tiananmen Square against the young Chinese who were demanding, as they are doing today with the Jasmine Revolution, freedom and democracy.
China has opened up to the West economically, but without linking production to environmental protection and labor safety, and it fails to make any concessions to democracy and pluralism.
This is not interference in China's internal affairs, as Beijing claims, but the appeal of men and women, movements, and parties who intend to build a world free from intolerance on every continent.
The Beijing government should look at what is happening in the world to understand that if it does not change, it will be the events of history and the Chinese citizens that will change China.
Please.

This is the direct assessment of the impact on SMEs in the triumphant Lisbon project and the Europe 2020 strategy, on which it is even being decided to focus the resources of the next multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.

I can only reiterate what thousands of European citizens and taxpayers are asking themselves: what is the point of Europe if it is not capable of solving the continent's economic problems, cannot speak with a single voice on foreign policy, and squanders money?
I hope that what Commissioner Tajani has said several times will come true.
I hope that the revision of the SME code will truly be able to simplify bureaucracy, ensure access to credit recovery, and facilitate internet adoption.
The directive on late payment represents a concrete and real achievement, but it is the result of political will rather than Euro-propaganda.

If the costs of yet another strategy will only fund more talk, I call on the European institutions to make amends to the dozens of small entrepreneurs in my region, Veneto, who have taken their own lives before seeing their small business fail.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, while Europe pretends that nothing is happening, Europol's 2011 report on organised crime states that with the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into Schengen, powerful Turkish, Russian and Albanian criminal organisations will be able to expand their activities throughout Europe.
Furthermore, to quote verbatim, illegal immigration from Turkey will spread to the Bulgarian coast, and drug and human trafficking by Turkish and Albanian criminals will increase.

Still on the subject of human trafficking, Romania and Bulgaria's entry into Schengen could provide Bulgarian criminals and new Roma communities with new opportunities to increase their already substantial trafficking operations to the rest of Europe.
In the end, an increase in illegal immigration from Turkey and in drug and human trafficking, less security for European citizens.
Europe wants to do organized crime a big favor.
The Northern League party will always be opposed to this kind of reckless decision.
Those who vote in favor of this report tomorrow will bear the responsibility for a vote that will open a highway to organized crime leading straight to the heart of Europe.
Thanks to the Treaty of Amsterdam, environmental policy and sustainability policy have gained greater importance, and sustainability policy has become more significant.
The focus was on the integration between economic and environmental policy and on the inclusion of environmental issues in policies and other sectors.

Key areas include climate change, sustainable transport, nature and biodiversity, health and the environment, as well as the use of natural resources and waste management, and the international dimension of sustainable development.
In June 2006, the European Council, in its conclusion, invited the Union and its Member States to extend national accounts to the key aspects of sustainable development.
National accounts must therefore be supplemented by an integrated economic and environmental accounting system, capable of providing fully consistent data.
I voted in favour of this proposed regulation because it creates new uses for national accounting data and for environmental statistics and for other statistical areas.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, my vote in favour of the Garriga report on the European Union's forthcoming financial perspectives is based on the conviction that, precisely in one of the most critical moments,

For the so-called European spirit to be decisive, it is essential to insist on and prevail in the indispensability of providing the Union with credible tools, starting with an adequate financial endowment.
Therefore, the request for an additional five is a fair and necessary one for the next budget, perhaps not sufficient, but indispensable for providing answers to the major issues before us.
addressing real problems such as stronger cohesion between regions, greater capacity for research and innovation, and a stronger capacity to generate growth and provide employment.

adequate, none of these problems will find a sufficient answer, starting with the introduction of this intermediate category in cohesion policy, which only makes sense if this does not harm the other existing categories.
That is why I voted in favour and I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow the recommendations in this report.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the new Hungarian Constitution reduces the scope for intervention by supervisory bodies such as the Constitutional Court and increases the powers of the executive, thus calling into question the normal balance of power.
Social rights are being emptied: the state provides subsidies to those in need only if they agree to perform public works.
The right to self-defense is even enshrined in law, allowing people to possess weapons in their homes without a license.
The right to abortion is prohibited and strongly discriminatory rules are introduced against homosexuals.
All of this is contrary to Directive No 2000/78, which establishes a general framework for combating discrimination.

I therefore ask the Commissioner how she intends to intervene, considering that the fundamental rights of the new Hungarian Constitution are poorly compatible with those of the European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
We are about to vote on a strategic document of great importance that provides a solid framework for negotiations on the financial perspectives for the post-2020 period.

starting from the demand for consistency between objectives and instruments, between the new role that European institutions are called to play after Lisbon and in the face of the recession, and the resources that we collectively decide to invest.
This consistency also implies a serious response to the demand for innovation that emerges from public opinion, from the recipients of EU policies, and from European social and productive forces.
We did it for cohesion, a crucial chapter in deciding what we want and what the European Union will be in the coming years.
it tells us that cohesion is today a vital component of the European project, an important asset for all to safeguard, protect, and renew.

Particularly critical on this front is the effort made regarding the hypothesis of introducing an intermediate category of regions, especially because in many cases the years of recession that we have behind us have
bridging internal gaps, making efficient and adequate support for the less developed regions of Europe even more important, fighting waste and clearly outlining the development policy.
However, I believe that the challenge of intermediate categories with the safeguard clause is a challenge we must accept in order to open a new phase in politics.
of cohesion in Europe and also to underpin the cohesion policy with the more balanced, more sustainable development that we want to ensure for Europe in the coming years.
I would also like to join in thanking Mr Langen and the other colleagues with whom we have worked to put together this complex report.
I think what the honourable Member pointed out is particularly important
Langen, when he said that we want to maintain the purpose, the scope of this regulation, staying true to what was the G20 mandate in Pittsburgh in 2009.
The fundamental goal is to bring the majority of over-the-counter derivatives onto regulated platforms to avoid continuing to be exposed to a high degree of

risk and speculation. When it comes to exchanging, as has happened, to insure four hundred million dollars without collateral, that is, without adequate reserves, one can understand the risks we are running.

That said, however, I would also like to touch upon two problems: the first problem is the relationship with the Council, the second problem is the organic nature of the proposal for the reform of financial markets that we must push forward.

I raise the first problem regarding the Council, and I say this very clearly: the feeling is all too often that the Council represents an obstacle to making swift and effective progress on the reform of financial markets.
I hope that the new Presidency will take charge of this problem, because on this occasion too we must put into
I expect the process to take longer, largely due to the positions, difficulties, and conflicts that arise within the Council.
It is a problem that also concerns the procedure we want to follow.
The second issue is the organic and specific nature of the measures.
It's not just the measure on OTCs, there's also the measure on short selling and other things.

I would like to highlight two points: the specific issue of the commodities market, a particular market that requires specific anti-speculative measures, and the problem of local authorities' exposure to derivatives in EU countries.
I think these are issues that Parliament must address.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the Fukushima incident continues to produce very serious consequences, with the loss of sea and radioactive water six hundred fifty times higher than the legal limits.
The risk of food products being contaminated is high.
Europe has established very strict controls, but this applies exclusively to fresh produce.
No protective regulations have been issued for processed products, particularly for canned fish.
We import 370 tons of canned tuna, and the main suppliers are Southeast Asian countries that import fish from Japan.
This means that canned fish imported into Europe could contain Japanese fish.
It is crucial and urgent to provide precise information about the place of origin.
Today, in fact, consumers know where the box was produced, but not the place where the fish was caught.

The Commission has recently acknowledged this and plans to address this gap with the reform of the common fisheries policy, which, however, will not come into effect for another two years, just as the Sommer report, under discussion in this plenary, will not be effective for another three years.
We must not create alarmist situations, but consumers have the right to urgent and transparent information.
The Commission must intervene as soon as possible.
Mr. President Tusk, your speech gives us hope, and we hope that the Polish Presidency will contribute to the fight against the Europe of egoism.
national policies without a vision for the future, which would be a contribution to a Europe that truly thinks of itself as an integrated entity with a common destiny.
But, as you rightly said in your speech, a Presidency has concrete problems to face and solve.
In this short time, I want to point out two crucial issues on the economic and financial crisis front.
First issue: the reform of financial markets.
It is not a technical problem, it is a major democratic issue of our time. The times are too long, we need to resolve issues such as the reform of short selling and OTCs.
Second point, we are facing the issue of financial transaction taxation, we need to get to the heart of the matter, and we expect the Polish Presidency to make a concrete contribution in this regard.
More than twenty years have passed since the Schengen agreements were signed.
No one disputes the advantages of free movement, but it must be acknowledged that the current system is no longer suitable for current and future needs.

This is why the Member States and the EU as a whole must work to revise the mechanisms governing Schengen, so that freedom of movement does not come at the expense of our citizens' legitimate need for security.

As far as we know so far, the Commission's guidelines may also be partly acceptable, especially regarding the introduction of a mechanism that allows states to temporarily reintroduce border controls in case of an emergency.
We must see, however, how this will happen and whether the statements will be followed by actions, especially concrete results.

Certainly, a general reform of the European border protection system will also be necessary, especially the external borders, where Frontex must become an agency with real powers of intervention and support for national authorities as soon as possible.
We must protect our external borders if we want to continue with this Schengen.
It is time for courageous choices in this Europe if one does not want to merely survive.

The crisis has profoundly affected the real lives of European citizens and businesses and, if we do not react, risks irreversibly lowering the social and cultural quality, well-being, and future of young people and Europeans.

Far more than cohesion and prosperity values, getting out of the crisis means creating remedies for the identified causes, remedies against speculation, which, if necessary, must also have their nails cut, by imposing strict rules on financial markets.

remedies against recession, remedies against an unbalanced development model that has placed the person a step below profit, remedies against the resurgent nationalism that prevents Europe from making the choices that are its responsibility today.

Above all, it is time to define the tools, the resources, including new ones, to move forward, to ignite the engines of growth, through research, innovation, training, support for productive investments, infrastructure and work, because without work people are without dignity and without rights.
This report, thanks to Pervance Beres and colleagues, indicates a possible strategy for a Europe proud and aware of its role.
It is now up to European leaders, if there are any, to take responsibility for implementing it.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, behind the widespread prosperity of our continent there is a hidden Europe, often invisible, which we discuss in terms of numbers, statistics, sociology and not as real people, often women and children or the elderly, that is, the most vulnerable population.
But Europe will not be credible with its citizens if it does not learn to be consistent, and we here want to be consistent in this Parliament, at this stage of Europe's life.

If we say that we are founding the Union on values and human rights, I don't believe we can interrupt or cut a program for those who don't have food, for those who don't have the right to food, to access to food, so drastically.

fundamental, due to an unresolved legal issue, it is an agricultural fund, it is a social fund and if it is social, Commissioner, it must not be at the expense of other social programs, but it must be a new, ad hoc fund, with appropriate resources.
Let's say we want to ensure food safety for Europeans, but the first right to safety is to have food, and then to have it be healthy.
So here is our consistency and our commitment.

Therefore, a legal solution must be found that provides continuity and, with the help of non-governmental organizations and volunteer work, guarantees the first fundamental human right, the right to food.
Mr President, just to support this report and to underline two aspects in particular, one because it fits into the current debate on the
review of the common fisheries policy and the fundamental option, which is linked to the regionalization of a policy that has shown all its weaknesses in recent years due to its centralization.
This phase of regionalization finds a particular application in the Black Sea.

I believe that the elements contained in my colleague Iotova's report describe a particular situation, but one that is also repeatable in the rest of Europe. The situation in the Adriatic Sea is no different.
of the Tyrrhenian or Aegean Sea, that is, the interactions, especially between European and non-European fishing, are often very harmful to European markets and European consumers.
The second issue I would like to quickly highlight is the call for a common coastguard.
There is no politics without an exercise of control.

Controls today are carried out by disparate forces across Europe. I believe that the time has come to understand how one of the first European law enforcement agencies, namely the coast guards, can have a common management, greater correlation, and, why not, a single European body.
With this hope, I fully support the contents of my colleague Iotova's report.

Thank you, Mr. President. The disaster that struck the Gulf of Mexico over a year ago prompted the European Commission to reconsider the legislation related to the operation of offshore oil platforms.
The European Parliament, with this report, has also wanted to express its position on the matter, approving a text that requires adequate technical and financial capabilities.
aims to establish high safety standards for industry operators, thereby establishing the European Union's leading role in promoting the safety of offshore activities.
The new measures on the subject requested from the Commission will have to focus on international coordination and a realistic approach that combines all existing excellence.
in the sector at the level of procedures and avoids the creation of new bodies or additional bureaucracy that would risk moving away from achieving concrete final objectives.

In concrete terms, the report, in addition to greater accountability for operating companies, calls for improved mechanisms for communication and sharing of information and knowledge, and advocates for the strengthening and expansion of the role and competencies of the European Maritime Safety Agency.
It is for all these reasons that I consider the result achieved to be positive, thanks to the negotiation on this text to which we have expressed our support.
I thank my colleagues Zeber and Schilakakis, and I also thank Commissioner Edegard.

I believe that we are here today to discuss and reason in order to truly achieve a strong European climate policy, capable of safeguarding economic development and the well-being of European citizens.
International climate policies, as has been noted so far, have primarily focused on reducing CO2 emissions.
The proposal highlights how we must also tackle the fight against other anthropogenic emissions that cause the formation of tropospheric ozone, impacting climate change.

Many things have already been mentioned that I believe it is important to keep in mind. Today, we are able to do this at absolutely reasonable costs, we have the necessary technologies at our disposal. And while it is undoubtedly the CO2 emissions that have the most significant impact,

While it is undoubtedly true that the other greenhouse gases present in the atmosphere are present in much smaller percentages, it is also true that their potential is very high, and that we could therefore achieve significant results in just a few years or decades.
important.
There are signs, the Commissioner also reminded the United States, I saw a study published in Nature by the scientific agency of the American Department of Commerce with which I find...

I think there are many points of contact with the analysis carried out by our colleagues, and therefore I imagine that these will also be things that will enable Europe to present itself in Durban with an even stronger, more concrete and more important position.

I will conclude by recalling, as has already been mentioned, that in the extraordinarily difficult and delicate moment we are experiencing - we were talking about the homeless just a few minutes ago - there is a sensitivity among European citizens that we must take into account, and therefore, considering that the great...

For sensitivity, obviously, comes first, and for jobs, we should be able to run a communication campaign that clearly explains to citizens what we concretely want to do in terms of development, their well-being, and job protection.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the single market, free movement, the Lisbon Treaty are all elements that have come into play regardless of a change in our way of legislating, in the European way and in the national way.

it is necessary to follow up on the commitments that have arisen from these occasions, in particular, it is necessary to truly initiate a phase of simplification of the legislative system, a phase of simplification that must produce a different dialogue between Europe and the individual States.

I would start right from our documents, and I take this opportunity to suggest a kind of clarity test on our documents. When we produce a white paper or a green paper, everything must be more comprehensible.

This virtuous phase of initiating legislation is to assign a specific delegation to a European Commissioner who specifically deals with clarifying legislation and the relationships between the States and Europe itself.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Mr Council representative and Commissioner, I would like to begin by welcoming, as other colleagues have done, the anti-corruption package that the European Commission approved last June 6th.
Corruption is a transnational phenomenon and measures on a European scale are needed to combat it.
According to Eurobarometer estimates, the vast majority of our European citizens believe that Europe must do more.
How can one blame them?

In many Member States, there has been a lack of political will to combat corruption, as evidenced by the fact that there are still European countries that have not signed the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

If we consider the devastating impact of corruption on democratic processes, citizens' rights, and trust in the rule of law, it is clear that the national anti-corruption measures adopted by the Member States to date are insufficient to contain an expanding phenomenon.

It is the European Union that must provide a unified and strong response, especially now, in the midst of an unprecedented economic crisis, which is affecting people's lives, the sustainability of welfare systems, and the ability of institutions to guarantee essential services.
Corruption causes the loss of one hundred and twenty billion euros every year, equivalent to one percent of the European Union's GDP, and daily deprives the Union and its Member States of resources.
they could be used to provide essential services such as education, childcare, employment, transport, in short, to divert clean resources from supporting people.
We therefore need more courage and more firmness, both by monitoring the implementation of anti-corruption measures and by intensifying and toughening up anti-corruption measures at the Union level.

In particular, we cannot talk about fighting corruption if we are not able to adopt at least minimum standards for defining the crime of corruption, which are not included in the package that has just been passed.
The same applies to the definition of uniform parameters for measuring the extent of the phenomenon in member countries, which is essential for preparing an effective response.
We are in favour, for example, of relaunching the network of EU contact points against corruption, as proposed in the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
The crisis is not of yesterday, it has been existing for some years already.
Has the time perhaps come to critically assess the policies followed so far? Has everything always been done well?
We have always carried out appropriate analyses of the situation.
the right approach was chosen
Did the same European Central Bank, which as Minister Rostovsky says saved Europe, always do the right thing even when, fearing inflation, it raised interest rates?
President Barroso identifies a problem: the speed of the markets and the slowness of politics. But is this the only problem?

Of course, if one considers that we are still in the implementation phase of July 21, this should at least suggest that summits and their conclusions should be better prepared and organized, but politics will always be slower than the markets.
So the point is to look further ahead, shifting the focus to fighting unemployment and development.

This is the ground that the European Commission must choose. Even today, in President Barroso's speech, there was more concreteness on the deficit and less on the indications of growth and development.

The Commission should go beyond its weakness, say that the priority is fighting unemployment and creating jobs, redistributing wealth and a public investment strategy, while also changing the rules of the new European stability pact.
Mr President, I believe that the challenge of the coming years is to ensure that Europe, as has been said, maintains its leading position.
a world-class tourist destination and, at the same time, be able to enhance, both in terms of environmental protection and competitive capacity, all its territorial assets.

It is a challenging and unpredictable task, not only in light of the opportunities, but also of the aggressiveness of other countries in this sector, from other continents, from China to India to Brazil.
Now, in this context, as Commissioner Tajani pointed out, it becomes crucial, as also noted in the opinion of the committee that we approved in the Committee on Regional Development,
to put together a strong overall EU strategy on tourism, with an enhancement of the role of the regions and territories.
In this sense, full involvement from the outset is essential, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity of the regions and local authorities.
Furthermore, I believe that the development of integrated tourism networks and projects should be encouraged, starting with the creation of partnerships for the exchange of best practices.
I also think the proposal to identify a European label capable of defining high quality in tourism products is a good one.
Obviously, it will be up to the Commission to better define the priorities, especially from a financial point of view, to ensure that Europe's leadership is maintained in the future.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the preparation of the common strategic framework for the funding of research and innovation represents one of the greatest opportunities that European development and economy have ahead of them.

It is indeed a matter of acting on the lever that can truly trigger a moment of growth and also of new skilled employment, such as that of researchers and young people who dedicate themselves to new opportunities for innovation, technology, and related professions.
One observation, in particular, emerges from this work: that we must increasingly emphasize in Europe research and innovation that lead to practical application.

to give birth to new companies that come up with new patents and that do not remain purely basic research, pure knowledge which is important yes but not enough to really trigger the engine of development.

The second observation is the relationship with local authorities, regions, and territories, which are also an important tool for territorial planning and for bringing together research, universities, centers of excellence, and businesses.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the European schools were created with the aim of ensuring access to education in their mother tongue for the children of officials of the European institutions who are called to work and live abroad in a cultural context different from that of their country of origin.
The first European school was established in Luxembourg back in 1953 on the initiative of a group of officials.
Over the years, considering the positive impact of this form of teaching, as many as fourteen European schools have been established within the various Member States.

While recognizing that the system of European schools represents a necessity rather than a luxury, it is evident that, more than fifty years after the creation of the first European school, this system may present obsolete aspects and must in some way be adapted and adjusted to new economic and social needs.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Mr Cavada, which calls for greater involvement of the European Union in supporting and coordinating the actions of the Member States, which are called upon to work towards developing and improving the European schools system.
It is known that investing in education means investing in the future of our young Europeans.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, in recent decades, there has been an exponential increase in the number of natural disasters that have caused the death of tens of thousands of people in various parts of the world.
Last year, within the Development Committee, I followed the work on the report on the European Union's capacity to respond to disasters.
it emerged how much still needed to be done to ensure a coordinated response from the European Union in the face of the increasing number of earthquakes, floods, and tsunamis.
The European Union's response to the Haiti earthquake, for example, clearly demonstrated the complexity of the existing tools and procedures.

Although the Member States and Community institutions acted promptly in terms of sending humanitarian aid, the management of the crisis raised a number of issues in terms of efficiency, coordination and transparency.
That is precisely why I voted in favor of the text by my colleague Elisabetta Gardini, which calls for greater efficiency in all phases of disaster management and improved coordination.
among the parties involved and a simplification aimed at avoiding unnecessary duplication and waste of time that would hinder the provision of rapid and effective aid.
It's just a good initiative, I believe that instead it will be about building a European policy towards tourism.
