The European brand is a good idea, but I want to focus on two issues. There is no such thing as seaside or coastal tourism without a coastal planning policy.

I believe that the time has come for Europe, precisely to protect this important sector, to produce an initiative in which the concept of the sea and the concept of the coast is not limited to a kind of urban planning that ends at the water's edge and does not involve the sea as a whole.
I believe that an integrated policy in this sense is useful, as well as it will be necessary to build everything that lies behind the claims of rural tourism. Rural tourism can be
an excellent source of income for disadvantaged areas, for areas where there is no longer any work, where it is important instead that depopulation does not continue and there is human settlement.

Well, it's not enough to just make statements there, but one should suggest that Europe and individual states intervene on the fiscal lever. Doing tourism in rural areas might mean paying less tax, perhaps this is how a real opportunity is truly built for the tourism resource and for those who live there.
Thank you, Mr. President. I want to express my congratulations on the work done by Mr. Fidanza, which logically fits into the framework of actions.
undertaken and promoted at Community level in the field of tourism, after the Lisbon Treaty assigned the EU new powers in this sector.
I share and wish to emphasize the assertion of the importance of a Europe as a unified destination for certified and quality tourism, and the desire to promote this.
same idea, translating it into actions at the level of structures, allocation of resources, funding, coordination of actions between the various levels of government of the countries of the Union.

an approach to be valued and rewarded, given that the sector in question, with its implications in terms of percentages of GDP produced, employment and new opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises,
Companies that focus on protecting and enhancing the environment are well-positioned to develop and thus respond to the main challenges posed by current events.
For all these reasons, I consider this report to be positive, an important signal in the direction of promoting a European policy for tourism.
Mr President, even for recovery, three small considerations: we need more Europe here too.
I believe it is inevitable that on certain issues there is indeed an attitude where not only is more Europe desired, but it is also built.
More Europe means, for example, starting to really think about a common road safety police force, with identical rules in terms of safety protection.
More Europe means having a European training policy, not simply delegating this to individual states, but building, for example, a genuine training policy.
Regarding schools, young people, and even those at higher risk‚Äîa moment ago, motorcyclists were mentioned, but we could also talk about truck drivers.
More Europe means having common tools within machines that improve safety conditions.
I believe that they are a timely strategy to be built with car manufacturers and with European vehicle production.
Here, I believe that if all of this falls within the framework of a common policy, I truly think that perhaps conditions will improve.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, this report addresses a topic that is that of global food security. Global means that this topic is not only that of world hunger in the poorest countries, but that the topic of food supply concerns all communities, including those in the most developed countries.

highlight some lines such as the essential one of coherence between European policies and this goal of global food security because we are an institution that preaches very well but is often not consistent in its choices.
I just want to outline, however, three other innovative three-line titles that I believe we should develop more.
Today, the first line of food supply is at risk due to price volatility caused by speculation on food products, which must be curbed if not prevented, including derivatives.
Secondly, the issue of land grabbing, which I believe should be the subject of some form of treaty or negotiation, because democracy is at risk, as well as the survival of many peoples.
Third, coherence between supply and energy policies.
We cannot, in order to produce new energy, prevent food from being produced for the peoples of the world.
I voted wholeheartedly in favour of this report by Mr Zimmer, firstly for a reason of
This is purely a political issue, because I believe it is necessary to bring back to the center of the initiative of the entire European Union this major issue of food safety.

It is not just about helping developing countries to address this issue more effectively, but the food crisis, as it is expected that by the year 2050, demand will increase by more than seventy percent.

agricultural products is a major issue that, if not addressed in time and with determination, will become one of the main threats, if not the most important threat, to stability, peace and even democracy, as has been seen.

That is why I believe it is essential that the entire European Union, together with its member countries, make every necessary effort, starting with adequate economic investments, as indicated in the report, in this direction to seriously address this major issue.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, greetings to the Commission. I must truly thank all the people who have contributed in recent weeks and months to the production of this document that we are voting on today in this Chamber.
We worked, I must say, very well and a truly constructive debate developed.
The motion for a resolution that we are voting on today is the result of truly collective work and is the fruit of the contribution of all political forces and of the entire Parliament.

I believe a very strong common sensitivity has developed regarding this issue, also because, we must remember, we live in an era that is truly characterized by an exponential increase in catastrophes.
The numbers, if we look at them in their rawness, are very eloquent. The number of catastrophes in the world has quintupled, if we think that in 1975
seventy-eight catastrophic events had been recorded, while today we have nearly four hundred calamitous events per year.

Unfortunately, in the last twenty years, the victims of these disasters have been ninety thousand, and more than twenty-nine million people have been affected by the disasters, while the economic losses amount to two hundred and fifty billion euros.
It is evident that we are facing phenomena of such magnitude that require a stronger response, a more effective response, and a truly strong commitment on our part.
We all have the images of the earthquake in Haiti, the flood in Pakistan, and what happened in Japan etched in our minds.
Europe itself experiences sudden floods and fires on its territory every year, and we must not forget the ash cloud that followed the eruption of the Icelandic volcano.
There is no need to go further to assert how important the work being done here in Parliament is, following two principles.
fundamental, which are our guiding stars, the principle of solidarity, which is reinforced by the solidarity clause in the Lisbon Treaty, and the principle of subsidiarity.
We are moving along these lines.
The European Union's intervention has always been generous and effective in the past, as evidenced by the tireless work of our Commissioner Gheorgheva, but today we need to make a qualitative leap.
A qualitative leap that we are ready to make to move from an ad hoc response to a response instead where the reaction
it can be enhanced by the prior identification of existing resources in the Member States made available to the European Civil Protection Mechanism.
It is also important to emphasize that for this qualitative leap and for moving from information sharing and emergency response to the planning and monitoring role.

We hope for coordination, the fundamental role of services like GMS, and I take this opportunity to also express the concern about what is happening regarding the budget for these new technologies, which are essential.
We have included the importance of communication with citizens because, as the Japanese experience has also taught us, it is never enough and is never sufficient.
and we are waiting for the Commission, to which we ask to present the proposal on civil protection in legislative form as soon as possible.

Oppressed ethnic minorities, Christians forced to live in hiding to practice their faith, priests barbarously murdered while the authorities do nothing, an anti-Western foreign policy - this is Turkey today.
My party, the Northern League, has always been opposed to Turkey's entry into Europe, because it represents a potential Trojan horse for radical Islamism on our continent.
Today more than ever, we are convinced that the EU must put an end to accession negotiations.
The intolerable threats that Turkey has directed towards Europe must be met with an immediate response.
It is unacceptable for a third country to tell Europe what to do.
Cyprus is a full member of the EU and has the indisputable right to assume the rotating presidency.
Europe must send a clear signal and show itself ready to defend Cyprus by any means in the face of Turkey's political and military arrogance and overbearingness.
Let us immediately halt the accession negotiations and be prepared to suspend trade relations as well.
President, we are experiencing a decisive moment for the future of the euro and, with it, for the entire European project.
To have this awareness would mean to break free from a short-sighted logic that subordinates everything to an ideological desire for budgetary austerity.
We all want the accounts of the various states to be in order and we all want to reduce indebtedness.
However, it is clear that without a smart investment policy capable of revitalizing the economy, there will be no possibility of growth.
The only clear outcome of this approach is that, as always, the heaviest burden will be borne by the most vulnerable groups.
For this reason, together with the group of socialists and democrats, we voted against this report.
In fact, we continue in a single direction that is that of austerity without growth, a direction that has so far proved to be wrong.
I very much appreciated the work that my colleague Ferrera did on this report.
In fact, out of the package of six legislative proposals dedicated to economic governance, only this one did my group and I vote in favor of.

We did this because, among other things, a clause was included to protect social rights starting from collective bargaining, and there is also a strengthening of the role of Parliament in the adoption of delegated acts.

So, while we cannot change the overall balance of the package of six proposals, this report certainly represents a step forward in achieving, among other things, a surveillance system that takes fundamental rights into account.
And so, in this context, while we believe that a vision based solely on austerity policies does not produce positive results, this report certainly constitutes a positive note in a contrary trend.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Finland and the Netherlands have taken a stand in the Council for a very simple reason: Bulgaria and Romania are not currently able to guarantee effective border control and are embroiled in widespread corruption involving the political class and organised crime.
It is not the populist parties and movements who think this way, but Europol in its 2010 report on organized crime.
There is no populist propaganda, but a serious security problem.

If Bulgaria were to join the Schengen area at this time, police and security agencies predict that the Bulgarian borders, especially the maritime ones, would become an easy target for Turkish and Eastern European crime, and Bulgaria and Romania would become a hub for human and drug trafficking.

It is natural that some member states have many reservations about the actual ability of Bulgaria and Romania to ensure effective border controls against organized crime and corruption, and it is therefore absolutely natural that they opposed their entry into Schengen.
Allowing it now means paving the way for transnational crime and creating a breach in European borders, precisely where there is a very strong migratory pressure from Turkey.
The reasons are many and varied, and Europe cannot ignore them.
I would therefore like to know what the Commission and the Council's intentions are regarding this sensitive issue, which in my opinion has so far been dealt with...

in a sufficient manner and without taking into account the dangers that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania would entail, according to the competent bodies in the field of security and international crime.

In my opinion, the Commission and the Council should postpone the entry of these two countries into Schengen and only give the go-ahead when there is reasonable certainty that the entry of Bulgaria and Romania will not have repercussions on the security of European citizens.

Mr President, the crisis in Europe is entangling the problems of public budgets and private capital with those of the productivity of our companies in a vicious circle, and the specter of recession is present.
If, therefore, the priority of SMEs is crucial, I ask the Commission that we must absolutely, together with Parliament, ensure that our good principles are put into practice.
and that the legislative initiatives of the SBA, the Small Business Act, become concrete practice in the Member States, with a high level of effectiveness and quality.

One wonders, Commissioner, what would happen if all Member States brought forward the implementation of the directive against late payment? What a great advantage that would be for SMEs. So SME evidence is important, but we are still at the methodological level.

Of course, it is right to verify whether, when we legislate, we are truly doing so in the interest and to the measure of small and medium-sized enterprises, but we ask that we proceed with great consistency and tenacity in depth in creating this framework of opportunities that you have outlined.
We appreciate what the Commission is doing and we are ready, with the budget and the other possibilities we have, to support it.
I'll just say a word about credit.
Let's have a clear discussion with the banks, I say to you, Commissioner, because we need to help small and medium-sized enterprises.
Mr President, I cast my vote in favour of the text by my honourable colleague Mrs Wallis.
while not prejudicing the usual means of access to justice, I am convinced that an alternative dispute resolution ADR represents a quick and economical alternative to legal disputes.
In addition to being an effective tool for small and medium-sized enterprises, ADR can also have significant development online for the resolution of minor disputes.

Through joint efforts with the Member States, it is therefore necessary to promote the creation of a harmonized legal framework that, by strengthening citizens' confidence in the internal market, can help stimulate the European economy.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the report on the provisions for sectors placed on the market under the flexibility scheme, to which we have expressed our favourable vote, was inspired by a measured and realistic approach that has

This is achieved, on the one hand, by avoiding the setting of unrealistic and impossible-to-meet requirements, and on the other hand, by establishing a so-called flexibility regime that is structured around the provision of time phases and corresponding quantitative limits.

The allowed emissions plan provides for the release onto the market of a predetermined annual quota of tractors that meet certain characteristics, and in this way allows for the gradual adjustment to the set standards over time, without causing trauma to the affected production and industrial sectors.

Mr. Tattarella, the work carried out has been important and he has managed to carefully balance the needs dictated by the major challenges that the European Union is called upon to face at this time with those of environmental protection and the current context of economic crisis.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the current global economic crisis, even more severe than the one in 1929, has caused unsustainable imbalances in international economies in recent years.
Trade disparities between countries, financial markets lacking common rules, and instability in banking systems are all potential threats to financial and economic stability.
This resolution, which I support, urgently emphasizes the fundamental aspect of new rules and global economic coordination.

The economy needs a global governance system, open markets, high economic and social standards, more responsible monetary policy, and stricter oversight policies, and international decision-making bodies and economic organizations must be the main actors at the center of this new approach.

Europe, in particular, needs a transparent potential to reduce instabilities exacerbated by globalization, ensure far-reaching reforms aimed at promoting growth and reducing the debt of individual states.
This is the commitment that this resolution emphasizes to all countries.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I cast a vote in favour of the report by my colleague, Mrs Matera, which analyses the situation of single mothers, who today represent, as has already been mentioned, more than five percent of the population of the European Union.

The European Union therefore has a moral obligation to protect them, and the text approved today supports those policies that can provide concrete help for these women, such as benefits for their daily lives.
healthcare, flexible work opportunities that allow for a balance between private and professional life, priority access to affordable housing, and special unemployment benefits.
Only by adopting these measures can we meet the needs of an increasingly significant category in all advanced and industrialized countries.
Thank you, Mr President. The budget sets out a few clear and important objectives within the framework of the EU 2020 strategy. For this reason, I would like to thank the rapporteurs.
It is crucial to focus on investments and not just on prudent budget management.
The alternative would be to passively adhere to the speculative philosophy that characterizes our time.
We can no longer afford to pursue individual interests, but must finally represent a single, cohesive entity ready for confrontation.

I welcome the commitments made on pilot projects and preparatory actions in heading two, as well as the fact that funding for the integrated maritime policy will not come at the expense of other fisheries initiatives and programmes.

This will allow us to implement new policies for better management of marine resources through extensive research and exchange of data on fish stocks, imposing new project plans that in the Adriatic area can be used as best practices in other marine areas.

I conclude with a small postscript. In the context of future debates on the CFP, and particularly with regard to the Fisheries Fund, I hope that a greater effort will be made on fisheries control, the core of the fight against illegal fishing, but also the foundation for rebuilding fish stocks.
consider fish as a common good.
Mr President, the economic, financial and social crisis we are experiencing has clearly highlighted several weaknesses in the European economic and social model.

I believe that one of the most representative alarming data of the current situation is the almost six million jobs lost in the last three years, data that, as this situation continues, are destined to grow if we do not know how to react in a prompt and effective manner.

The text by my colleague Bastos emphasizes that in order to make concrete progress, we need better energy, better synergy between education, training, and the labor market, along with policies aimed at ensuring a better match between the demands and supply of this market.
For these reasons, Mr. President, I cast my vote in favor.
I cast a favorable vote on what was presented by Mrs. Angelilli, because it addresses a problem that, as a mother and a grandmother, deeply concerns me.

Protecting children from sexual exploitation, abuse and the disgusting world of child pornography means defending our children and grandchildren, and consequently defending the weakest members of society.
Greater prevention, harsher criminal action against those who commit such crimes, and more careful protection of children are the key points of the document voted on today.
Without a doubt, the path is difficult.

I am thinking in particular of the spread of child pornography material via the internet, which can only be combated through close collaboration between Member States, police authorities and providers.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the challenges posed by modernity and the report by our colleague Santa Fidina, to which we have given our favourable vote, require us to place the citizen in their role as a consumer outside the world.

at the heart of the Community debate and remind us that the protection of its interests cannot remain merely a principle enshrined at the level of the Treaty, but must be a concrete guiding principle of European Union policies.

to counter the possible involvement of organised crime in European sport, by calling, as in the text voted on today, for a common definition of sports fraud and harmonisation of sanctions at European level.

of politics, but if ever generosity - and I say this as someone from a country that was in opposition - the generosity of parties willing to do what is good for the country even without direct representation.

Policies to combat new and old poverty, which are unfortunately increasing in today's Europe, in the Europe of the crisis of recent years and also of one-way austerity policies, especially on the part of the States,

financial commitments, new resources, both in the European budget, including within the framework of the financial perspectives, and in European policies, as was just mentioned by the Social Fund to the ERDF, and in the budgets of individual states.

And above all, with regard to individual states, we should use the European semester to monitor year after year, in concrete terms, the policies that individual states dedicate to this fundamental challenge.

To make the goal of reducing poverty and social exclusion for approximately twenty million European citizens credible, it is therefore necessary to have consistency between the substantial resources that Europe must make available, the resources that the States must make available, and the concrete policies that we can implement.
It is estimated that approximately two billion euros will be needed from now until the year 2020 to achieve the goals we have set for ourselves.
This is the challenge that we highlight and place at the center of attention as the Budget Committee: the coherence between the financial resources we make available and the policies we implement.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, there are many workers in difficulty in our countries, the elderly, women, young people, disabled people and millions of individuals and families brought to their knees by the crisis and speculation.
In the face of this situation, we are here to discuss plans for support for Roma communities and housing to be provided to immigrants.
We must think about helping those who are truly in difficulty and provide financial and political support to the family, which is the institution on which our society is based.
We must help small and medium-sized enterprises that are being stifled by the crisis, because these SMEs are the real antidote to poverty and the true source of wealth in our countries.
We must give priority to our best forces, not pocket them to guarantee migrants a minimum income that Europe wants to impose from the other side.
Enough of the talk about the Roma and immigrants. Now we must give priority to the real outsiders.
If we look around carefully, we will see many of them, and it is certainly not necessary to enter a Roma camp to see them.
Europe must direct its efforts and funds towards these excluded people, now more than ever.

Mr President, I cast my vote in favour of the report on the work of the ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, which, thanks to the quality of the work carried out, has established itself as a key player in cooperation between the North and the South.
I myself, as a member of that assembly, participated in the meetings held in Brussels and the work carried out in Tenerife in April 2010 and in Kinshasa, Congo, in December of the same year.

It was precisely thanks to these visits that I was able to witness firsthand, as I had already done in 2009 in Angola, the sad conditions that certain peoples live in on a daily basis, and at the same time assess the efforts made by the ACP to improve things.

In conclusion, I feel therefore compelled to emphasize, in a particular historical and political moment, especially for the countries of North Africa and the Middle East, how the role played by the CP has been...

This is of fundamental importance, especially in the context of supervising negotiations for economic partnership agreements, promoting transparency in these processes and the development of disadvantaged local communities.
Mr President, Mr Zanicki, I personally find the idea of establishing a European heritage label interesting.

At a time when, due to the persistent economic crisis, a certain Euroscepticism is emerging in many Member States, I believe that an initiative of this kind can strengthen the sense of belonging of European citizens to the Union.

The defining element of the European label is not the beauty of a site, but the symbolic value that it has represented or represents for the integration of European citizens on the path towards improved inter-point dialogue.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, in December 2009 I attended COP 15 in Copenhagen as an official member of the European Parliament delegation.

It has been about two years, and regrettably, I must say that the work done and the commitments made in Copenhagen, then formalized in Cancun, will not be enough to achieve the goal of limiting the increase in the average annual temperature on our planet to two degrees Celsius.
Some major emitting countries, such as Japan or Russia, seem to be straying from their commitments, while others do not seem to be giving the climate change problem the appropriate priority.

Today, while expressing my vote in favor, I am aware that only with the great and firm will of the heads of state and governments in the world can we create the prerequisites for a comprehensive international agreement.
Internet-related services still have great potential, both for the economy and for a more participatory and inclusive society.
Today, during the transposition of the Telecom package, there is a risk of fragmentation of the European framework in national legislation.

The Commission's monitoring role will therefore be important, and I would also mention the role of BEREC, which some of us would have liked to see strengthened in the definition of the telecoms package.

The priorities we want to reiterate in this debate are: ensuring net neutrality, developing broadband infrastructure, developing more open software, ensuring access security and system interoperability, promoting the use of...

digital technologies in various industrial sectors, services, digital content production and new services, inclusion of currently excluded individuals, I am thinking of the disabled but not only them, defense of informational and cultural pluralism.

It will also be ensured that operators cannot impose blocks, restrictions, limitations, or discrimination against users, and that their transparency in commercial offers and all their activities is maximized.

Mr President, we are all aware of the important role played by the International Criminal Court, which is responsible for prosecuting those who commit war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.
Unfortunately, in recent times, the Court has increasingly been the target of unjust political attacks.
His arrest warrants have often been ignored, and for this reason the current budget is not proportionate to the efforts and commitment made.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text approved today because it is the task of the European Union to undertake all political, diplomatic and logistical actions to support the Court and guarantee its independence and proper and effective functioning.
Thank you, Mr. President. The phosphates present in household washing machine detergents end up in European water systems, rivers, streams, and lakes.

Phosphorus causes an acceleration in the reproduction of various life forms, as a result, algae and other rapidly developing plant species proliferate excessively when there is an increase in the presence of phosphorus in an aquatic environment.
This excessive growth of algae deprives other living organisms of oxygen, can also produce toxins that destroy fish and plant species, thus reducing the quality of the water itself.

I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text voted on today because in order to purify Europe's water resources, it is desirable to reduce the amount of phosphorus that flows into the waters of our continent.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the text presented by my colleague Mr Lisek analyses the possible measures to be implemented to reduce defence costs during a period of financial crisis that weighs heavily on the Community budget.
The main proposals concern better coordination of defense system planning, pooling and sharing of defense capabilities, and support for research and technological development.
I therefore agree with the rapporteur's view that the economic and financial crisis that has hit us could be an opportunity for integration of the
European Union defense policies, providing the impetus to develop and finally implement those ambitious reforms that have been stalled for years.
For these reasons, I cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, following the Arab Spring and the subsequent events, a revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy has become necessary.

It is clear that, at the present time, relations with the countries in question must be more focused on cooperation in order to ensure the priority of democracy and security on both sides of the Mediterranean.

In this regard, I believe that intercultural and interreligious dialogue is essential to strengthen mutual respect and tolerance with partner countries in the neighborhood, while also promoting the fight against terrorism and extremism.
For these reasons, Mr President, I naturally voted in favour.
Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday in Florence, an extremely serious event occurred that evokes horror and dismay.
A 50-year-old armed man opened fire in two markets in the city of Florence on five citizens of Senegalese origin, two of whom died and three are now hospitalized in serious condition.
The murderer then committed suicide.
It is the racist and xenophobic far right that wanted to kill people unknown to him, guilty only of having black skin.
Florence is my city and before I was elected to the European Parliament, I was mayor of Florence for ten years.
Florence is a civil and democratic city, awarded a gold medal for its resistance to Nazifascism.

Yet it was precisely in Florence that this abominable racist crime took place, demonstrating that Nazi-fascist madness can manifest itself anywhere and one must never think that it has been definitively eradicated.

Mr President, I ask you to express the European Parliament's condolences and to reaffirm this Parliament's commitment against all forms of intolerance and for the respect and rights of every human being.
Mr President, project management in war zones such as Afghanistan is not directly comparable to management in countries where the project has been implemented.
in developed countries or in countries not affected by conflict, with aid obviously also hindered by the stable security situation.
However, it is necessary to try to understand the reasons for the identified shortcomings, project management, and related risk factors in order to improve the situation as much as possible.
I share the rapporteur's position on this matter, which calls on the Commission to conduct a more thorough assessment of fraud, corruption, non-compliance, and the effectiveness of specific projects.
It is therefore necessary to increase the transparency and accountability of the use of EU funds and to help both Member States and other donors to avoid common mistakes.
Mr. President, we do not have time to go into the details or to engage in a full discussion, but I believe we must acknowledge that there are some points that remain very critical.
I share the concern about this green fund, because it remains a big question mark and a major concern as to where we will find the resources in these times.
But I believe that in order to be realistic we must recognize that things have changed this time in Durban.
The old approach, which no longer reflected the actual geopolitical situation in the world, has indeed been surpassed.
We continue to work on a photograph of the world in the nineties, a photograph that is quite old, if we look at it from the perspective of the year 2050, and is truly unsustainable.
We see that in 2050, among the world's top thirty economies, there should be nineteen countries that are currently still on the list of developing countries.
I believe that this change of pace is perhaps the most interesting aspect from a political point of view, and it has indeed been accurately highlighted by our colleague Florence.
I also think that we must no longer proceed in isolated compartments.
Recalling also what Mario Draghi, the Governor of the European Central Bank, said the other day right here in this institution, if we want to push in this sector towards the priorities, namely:

In terms of growth and employment, we really need to be concrete and focus primarily on green economy technologies to truly achieve sustainable development and meet the most important needs of our citizens.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, Europe is shrinking, stock markets are collapsing, the centralist Europe of financial lobbies is falling apart, but the Danish Presidency is opening its six-month term by promising total loyalty to the Commission's plans for creating a super economic government for the continent.
Instead of focusing on measures to save the destinies of 500 million citizens, the Danish government promises to act as a loyal watchdog of the Euro technocracy in the Council.
Other passages then do not find me in agreement at all.
First of all, I do not see how the acceleration of the EU enlargement process towards the Balkan countries can be proposed as a priority today.
There are other problems to address immediately before worrying about how to integrate countries in Europe affected by corruption and crime.
And then there's Turkey; the Danish government is strongly pushing for Turkey's accession.
Fortunately, Turkey is far from meeting the parameters set by the EU for entry.

But the real paradox is that, at a time when the euro is at risk of failure, it should be the Danish Presidency to save it, a country, Denmark, outside the eurozone, because, evidently, it has never trusted the euro.
President, honourable colleagues, the increase in violations of intellectual property rights has been recorded in recent years...
years risk undermining the strategy on intellectual property rights in the single market launched by the Commission in May 2011.
In order to counteract this phenomenon and safeguard the success of the intellectual property protection policy, it has been proposed to entrust certain tasks to:
tasks related to the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, established in 2009 at the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market.

This is in order to provide the observatory itself with human and financial resources capable of undertaking countermeasures against violations of intellectual property and awareness campaigns aimed at increasing consumer awareness of the risks associated with purchasing counterfeit products.

The vote in favour expressed in the report thus represents a moment of great importance in the fight against the trade in counterfeit goods and in defence of innovation, growth and competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as employment and the safety of European citizens.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, intellectual property may appear contradictory within its own definition, but conversely it has great moments of coherence.

I voted in favour of this proposal because its purpose, which is precisely to entrust the European Union's trademark and design registration office with certain tasks concerning the management of the European Observatory on Counterfeiting and Piracy, is necessary and indispensable in order to combat infringements of intellectual property rights.

The main objectives are to raise awareness among public and private sectors about the impact of counterfeit goods and to inform consumers about the dangers associated with purchasing counterfeit products.
On the basis of the 33 compromise amendments, an agreement was reached at first reading on 19 December.
The amendments stipulate that the title of the regulation and the name of the office should not be changed to reflect the European Observatory.
Moreover, the important and fundamental thing is the participation of civil society in the meetings.
This will make an integrative moment like the one we are celebrating with today's vote even more democratic and participatory.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, Mrs Lechner's report fits into that framework of actions aimed at improving services for citizens and businesses within the European Union.

The interconnection of central and commercial registers is indeed an excellent tool for making communications and the retrieval of information by citizens and businesses more accessible and, above all, faster.
Therefore, Mr. President, I cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, every time the situation seems to improve, new downgrades by the rating agencies arrive to shake up the trend of international markets.
Many European companies are in crisis, and on the employment front, the number of people, especially the young, chronically searching for a job is growing.

If austerity plans and the defense of the euro are necessary measures, then even more so are the profound revisions of the labor market at the national level, aimed at revitalizing the European economy.
Only by relaunching competitiveness will the European Union give new confidence to investors and promote the growth of new jobs.
Thank you. Honorable Bizzotto. I do not deny that the rights of homosexuals must be protected. What I deny, and in Italy it is like this, is that there are homosexual families.

There will never be homosexuals, simply because the family that needs to be protected, the one that the European Parliament should also protect, is the traditional family, the one formed by a woman, a man, and their children.
That all seems to me to be quite elementary.
This is the reality in Italy and in the other twenty-three countries.

Mr President, first of all, I too would like to join in the warm greetings from my colleague Mr Lechner, and also in the assessment of his work, which has proceeded with competence, tenacity and determination.

It was painstaking work, every now and then this proposed regulation got stuck and he pulled it out, started dealing with the Council, the Commission, the Legal Affairs Committee again, I think he can be proud of that.
I see that there is unanimous agreement towards him.

Coming to our regulation, I am also convinced that this is an important matter. Perhaps it does not make news in the newspapers, perhaps it is not considered high politics, but the construction of the European Union also passes through...
by working to meet the interests of citizens in their daily lives and especially of those millions and millions who, living on the borders of different states, are
They are faced with practices that are difficult to unravel, boring, and sometimes touch on the sensitivities at the heart of a family that politics generally finds difficult to understand.
The European Union should be proud to base its foundation on this kind of attention.

The solutions that have been proposed are intelligent and innovative. For example, those who are making a will have been given the option to choose between their habitual residence or their state of origin.
And this makes a decision more elastic, given that there are such profound, truly very profound, differences between one state and another, which could constantly complicate the issue of succession.
However, certainty was also given to the right because once the legal solution or habitual residence or country of origin was chosen, it was not possible to change it.

This results in a limitation of the judges' discretion and also a limitation of the conflicts that can arise, and therefore a more peaceful way of proceeding in this field, so there is more freedom and more certainty.

And then the certificate of succession, we believe that certificates are a trivial matter, this creates the conditions for the heir to have a condition of greater agility and certainty in the face of all the possible difficulties that could present themselves to him.
This is a fact that positively characterizes this law.

And then it's true, this law is not perfect, there are problems concerning the executor of the will or not, the practicality of direct inheritance and so on, but I don't just want to say another word of a political nature.
We hope that the Council will approve this text, we hope that it will become a regulation, but we must not put a tombstone on this text, because we cannot even entertain the idea of that.
England is in a different position with Great Britain, so, because Europe cannot do without Great Britain and therefore we should proceed to overcome these difficulties later.
Thank you, sir.
Mr President, the European Union has produced an enormous amount of laws, rules to build European law and has created the European area called the Stockholm plan.
There is a discrepancy between this corpus, this legislative monument, and the use that citizens make of it, which is numerically and percentage-wise very low.
On the other hand, national judges, the national lawyers of individual states, have grown up within the law of their own country and have a predominantly legal education in this regard.
sense, while we think that the true European judge is the national judge who changes his mindset and imbues himself with knowledge of European law.

For this reason, before discussing training, we must talk about extensive communication to citizens and legal professionals so that they become the bearers of this great innovation and increase the willingness to use the benefits of this right.
But above all, it is a grassroots movement that must be created in in-service training. You can't lecture like you're teaching schoolchildren when training adult, highly professional judges.

One must stimulate curiosity in handling one's own cases, in connecting with other colleagues, and in finding solutions, since today common law and civil law converge, they are no longer as distant as they once were within the legal culture.

This is the real point. In our proposals, and I am pleased that the European Commission has been convinced of these aspects, we are calling for a bottom-up reversal of the trend, with more legal studies and judicial training.
There is a very interesting example in Holland called Eurinfra, which is a network of officials in each court who disseminate this knowledge and encourage magistrates to do the same.
This is the essence of our project, and we hope it will receive full support from the Commission.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I would like to begin by expressing my sincere appreciation for the work done by my colleague Mr Giegold on this own-initiative report, and I would also like to remind you that he and I, along with others, are actively involved in the Social Economy Intergroup in this Parliament.

My political group, as you know, believes that the social model is one of the founding characteristics of the European integration project, therefore not a simple one, one of the many policies, but a policy that characterizes our project itself.

And these days, with attacks also linked to the need to cut public spending and so on, we still firmly defend this priority. We know that the social model can be updated and modified, but we also believe that it must be maintained, defended, and reaffirmed precisely as a priority.

Therefore, I believe that in this same vision, we must also value economic entities that engage in business, produce goods and services, such as cooperatives, and that play a very particular role in the so-called European social economy.

they reiterate that production can be achieved, good things can be done, and efficiency can be maintained even if profit is not the goal, but rather, for example, employment, welfare, enhancement of work, and contribution to the life of the local community are the objectives.

That is why it is important, I conclude, Mr President, that Europe provides the necessary tools for an active policy and that a good statute, not the current one, which is unusable, but a good statute for cooperatives, can be a way to help this important sector.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the role of the cooperative movement has always been important in building a more balanced and fairer economic dimension.
And at this moment, when we are going through one of the most serious economic and social crises since the post-war period, the role of cooperative societies becomes crucial.

As a result of the robust development of the cooperative dimension in the economy, there has been a consequent increase in employment, more skilled work, and a more balanced redistribution of the wealth produced.
It is therefore positive that the European Union has adopted a statute for cooperative societies, but now more than ever it is necessary for there to be a real simplification of the rules.
We need to give new impetus to the creation of a common European framework in the field of cooperation, and this must be done by helping and not by creating bureaucratic obstacles.
That is why I voted in favour of this resolution and I hope that the Commission and the Council will actively work to resolve the problems mentioned.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the salvation of millions of unemployed Europeans does not depend on the subtle assistance offered by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The data collected show that most of the Fund's beneficiaries are unable to find new employment, while the luckier ones are reintegrated into the labour market with fixed-term contracts of only six months.
In many cases, the unemployed give up on this fund because they doubt its usefulness.
The feico is not a solution and does not address the disastrous consequences of a European trade policy managed dangerously and too lightly by the Commission.

To combat the scourge of unemployment, which has now become structural, Europe must put a stop to its excessive openness towards the markets of developing countries, whose unfair competition is the primary cause of the failure of our companies.
Until Europe stops promoting economic self-harm by defending a short-sighted position towards global trade flows, our companies will continue to fail.
The fund can only provide temporary support, but it is not through training courses that our unemployed will find peace and security.
I believe that this is a great achievement for the European Parliament today.
President Buzek, when I said we needed to set up an anti-mafia commission, I remember that many colleagues from different countries said, "But the mafia is a problem of Sicily and Italy."

Today, having been recognized by colleagues from all over Northern Europe that there is a problem of organized crime in Europe and having the will to fight together, I believe is a great and important fact and I want to say thank you President and thank you to the whole Parliament.
Thank you, Mr. Sondal, for such a comprehensive presentation.

I would also like, first of all, to reiterate our solidarity with the families of the victims of the serious clashes that took place on December 16th in Zanusdaen, as well as our concern for the subsequent development of events.

What was originally essentially a union warning degenerated into the very serious accidents in which 17 people lost their lives and, in the days following the accidents, into the arrests of journalists and opposition representatives.

It is in everyone's interest, and as Kazakhstan has also demonstrated, to personally shed full light on the events, and I hope for this reason that today's will be distinguished solely as a positive opportunity for our Parliament to delve into what has happened so far.

and reiterate our call for an investigation that will reassure the international community that responsibility for the events in Zanonzhen will be clarified and those responsible will be prosecuted with the utmost respect for the principles of legality and the protection of human rights.

The delegation that I have the honour of chairing has had the opportunity, during some of its meetings, to listen to the explanations provided by the Kazakh authorities and also by some NGOs that are very active in monitoring events in this country.

The willingness of the Kazakh authorities to provide explanations, as well as their promises of further clarification, are certainly positive elements that should obviously be appreciated by all of us.
This is also why I would like to stress the need to maintain a certain balance, a balance that I would have liked to see highlighted in the text of the resolution that we will be voting on tomorrow.
it might have been appropriate to postpone the opinion pending the conclusion of the official investigations, to which it would have been useful to add an official mission by international bodies.

The undeniable need to clarify what happened and the need to appeal for increased efforts by Kazakhstan to improve progress on the path to democracy must also be constantly accompanied by a renewed commitment and open, constructive dialogue with this country.

Mr President, I voted in favour of this proposal because it aims to update the regulations from 2004 and 2009 in order to adapt to changes in the national legislation of the Member States in the field of social security and to keep pace with changes in social reality that affect the coordination of the security systems themselves.

The present proposal also incorporates proposals from the Administrative Commission for the Coordination of Social Security Systems, which aim to improve, modernize, and acquire, in accordance with Article 72(F) of the previous regulation.

The amendments contained in this proposal are intended to guarantee legal certainty for the parties concerned and also aim to ensure appropriate coordination at the level of the European Union of national social security systems.

It also reflects the regulatory changes that have taken place at national level and it was necessary to approve it because it takes into account the recent developments in cross-border mobility that affect the coordination of social security systems.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the credibility of the European Union at international level and the effectiveness of its human rights policies certainly depend on the condemnation of violations, abuses and human rights infringements.

crimes committed within the framework or outside of armed conflicts, the lack of respect for women, children, and in general the most vulnerable, and persecutions based on religion or belief, but it is also of absolute importance to avoid disparity

of the criteria between the European Union's human rights policy and other external policies, thus promoting democratization and supporting the fight against social inequalities, especially in times of economic crisis like the present.
Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues Asenis, Patraoneves, Romeva and their assistants for their substantial contribution to the success of this initiative.
Fish is a common good as it provides fifteen percent of the protein for over three billion people and the livelihoods of over five hundred million people depend on fishing and aquaculture.
This makes it a true global public good.
The approval of this statement indicates to the Commission a precise path on the need to spread responsible conduct, both among fishing communities and in consumer behavior.

The debate on the reform of the common fisheries policy now has an additional reason to support actions that move European policy away from the narrow focus on methods of resource extraction and towards a policy of rules that are directed inward.

On the contrary, a strategy is suggested that focuses on the sea as a privileged location to increase its reproductive capacity, both in inland waters and through innovative methods of fishing agreements with third countries.

Moreover, all of this is not only about protecting the environment and maintaining biodiversity, but also about responsible fishing, economic and social sustainability, and the specific interests of fishermen and our economies.
Thank you, Mr. President.
1.083.2006 submitted by the European Commission in a short time contains provisions aimed at creating a European risk-sharing instrument.

The objective is indeed to address the difficulties encountered by some Member States in raising the necessary private funding for the implementation of investment projects that can only be partially financed using public funds.

Although the path to overcoming the economic crisis is still long, I consider the work done to reach a compromise text that has set a ceiling for the funds allocated to the financial instrument and better defined the risk-sharing instruments to be fruitful.
Ladies and gentlemen, the economic crisis, technological development, and demographic changes have transformed society and the labor market in Europe in recent years.
To meet future skill demands, many people will need to complete higher education, and many workers will need to continuously add to and update their skills and knowledge while already being employed.

For this reason, I cast my vote in favor of the text by my colleague Tocque, which aims to modernize higher education systems in order to achieve the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy and promote social, cultural, and economic development within the Union.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President. I won't take up much of your time because in the short time I have, I would just like to touch upon a few things.

An absolute priority is that this program ensures the most effective implementation of existing regulations before setting new ones.

further binding targets and I am deeply convinced that in order to meet today's environmental challenges we must base future environmental policies on solid evidence and the most up-to-date scientific knowledge.

This has many limitations; it tells us how much we affect the environment, but it does not estimate, for example, the quality of the environment at all. So my concerns remain, and I urge everyone to take this into account.
When we talk about good examples for citizens, when we talk about the internal market and the possibility of creating opportunities for growth,
genuine and concrete opportunities for change in everyday life through the internal market, we can really use this example, we will need many more, obviously, as a result of our work.
