reduced, but because they can increase the supply of services and, in essence, also help the economy as a whole. So, I believe it is certainly a positive example, a good example.

But you will have understood, Commissioner, that there is a widespread desire in this Parliament, particularly in the speeches of two of my colleagues, Marturel Goebbels, from my group, but also many others.
others who would like this good example to become excellent and for us to move towards, in part this measure provides for it, a result of zero roaming, because it is possible.
We are utopian.

No, because a European internal market requires that tariffs be similar between domestic and non-domestic, there is no longer any difference when we talk about a single market, and above all because there is no technical justification for the increase in costs.
I remember when in 2007 we started talking about voice roaming, the first third generation roaming we had.
There was a certain disbelief and also a certain difficulty, not on the part of the Commission, I must give credit to its predecessor, Commissioner Reding.

There were a lot of difficulties, coming from those who said that the position of a true market does not involve regulation of tariffs, they are political prices, they belong to an old conception of the left, etc., etc. There were others who said that it does not work and so on, it slows down the market, but in the end we did it.
public interest and the realization that there were no technical justifications for the increase in costs led to
So the world is moving forward, things are becoming more and more possible, which is why I think an even more daring outcome is possible.
One last remark, because I cannot make any more, today we had a delegation of Tunisian citizens, I do not know if they are still present.
Perhaps among its many benefits, this extra-way expansion makes us understand that the possibility of use, without the fear of costs, also helps democracy.

In Europe, there are more than one hundred and twenty million broadband users, with at least seventy million citizens using their mobile devices to connect to the internet, work, study, or simply stay informed.
Thanks to this regulation, the European Union has finally decided to intervene in favor of all these consumers, reducing the cost of international telephone traffic, voice, data, and SMS.
This is a positive decision because the price reduction program will lead to an average decrease in rates of thirty-five percent over the next three years.

However, this is not enough in a difficult time like the present, both from an economic and an employment perspective. Communication, new technologies, and innovation are primary assets that Europe must defend with more courage.
Every European citizen must be able to move freely between member states, using the telephone rate set by their national operator.

No more fraud and exorbitant bills for those traveling within the EU. If we really want to give a concrete response to citizens, let's create a kind of telecommunications Schengen, which no longer imposes different tariffs on citizens depending on the countries in which they operate.
Mr President, colleagues, I was part of that delegation from the European Parliament that went to Sicily in November last year.
Our head of delegation Cecilia Wistrom wrote a letter to the Italian minister, the Minister of the Interior Chancellor received a response that gave us fairly clear answers.

I would like to point out, above all, that after that visit to Italy, the government changed, and the approach to the situation also changed, but the situation itself in the countries from which the migratory flow predominantly originated also changed.
However, this should not distract from the need for a careful analysis of what happened and also of the current situation.
The most relevant fact that is still relevant today is Lampedusa's status as an unsafe port, the closure of the first aid and reception center in Contrade Embriagola following the fire of the
September 2011 damaged it, but only partially: a dormitory was destroyed, one out of seven buildings in the structure was damaged, and the project was effectively cancelled.

Now, apart from the consideration that in the Mediterranean the only unsafe port was that of Tripoli under Gaddafi, and I do not find this analogy flattering, given that the migratory flows, even if significantly reduced in number, also for seasonal reasons,

They have certainly not stopped. It is important that a first aid and reception service operates and functions in Lampedusa, which is the first port of call for those arriving from the other side after journeys that are certainly not easy or risk-free. And the Somali shipwreck survivors know this well.

In April of this year, after seeing ten people die on the boat they were traveling on, or the twenty who were transferred from Linosa because there was no room in other reception centers, or the eighteen who are still living in the stadium's locker rooms on Linosa.

And the Cala Creta tourist residence, where they are currently being unwelcomed, is certainly not a CIE or a Cara, and, most importantly, in the meantime, both the healthcare system and the possibility of requesting asylum have been dismantled in Lampedusa.
Everything is entrusted to the goodwill and kind hearts of the carabineri on duty or the citizens and volunteers of Lampedusa.
Another consideration to be made is the function that the center itself had assumed in the recent past.
Allowing thousands and thousands of people to gather in a place that, due to its capacity and intended function, could only accommodate a few hundred, against all legal and ethical norms, is...

Allowing a territory of just a few square kilometers, already difficult due to its location and logistical challenges, to be forced to accommodate a number of people greater than its own population must be referred to.
reflect on the responsibilities for a situation of extreme tension that then escalated into
the fire itself.
I believe that my colleague Rinaldi's excellent report was successful in the Chamber.
I absolutely share the flattering opinion on the report.

Nevertheless, I would like to raise a small issue: our Europe, in relation to this new world that is trying to find democracy and different economic conditions, is a Europe divided by the Mediterranean.

It is precisely a particular attention to the Mediterranean that I would like the Commission to focus on, both with regard to environmental aspects and with regard to economic transactions that are in the Mediterranean.
The Mediterranean is the fishing ground.
We are building a new fisheries policy in Europe that will set very strict rules on the part of Europe.
On the other hand, there are no rules.
So why not use forms of fisheries agreements, support for these countries so that those countries apply the same rules that apply in Europe?

This would be beneficial for European fisheries, it would be beneficial for the sea, for environmental conservation, to ensure that this divide becomes less and less of a divide, and more and more a homogeneous place upon which to build the future of Europe and of this new world.

Following the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the European Parliament has become a full-fledged institutional player in the field of security policies and therefore has the right to actively and decisively participate in setting the priorities of the internal security strategy and the security model of the Union.

The report by my colleague Borsellino identifies the five key areas for which concrete actions have been proposed and calls for greater judicial and police cooperation between Member States to combat organized crime and terrorism.
I believe it is of particular importance to strongly consider the development of prevention policies, which are a fundamental tool for ensuring a European area of freedom, security and justice.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the foundations have been laid for the development of integrated criminal law within Community law.

While the importance of mutual recognition of the harmonization of protection standards and the principle of the presumption of innocence remains, it is important to emphasize that the law must be extremely clear and easily understandable, so that everyone can clearly understand which actions constitute a crime and which do not.
This is particularly true for directives that must be reciprocal to national law.
Any lack of clarity could, in fact, give rise to divergent interpretations of the law.

I therefore believe that only close collaboration between European institutions on the principles and methods to be followed can guarantee a coherent and high-quality European strategy in the field of criminal law.
Mr President, the European Union safeguards the general interests of consumers against unfair business practices, misleading advertising and abusive contractual clauses.
There is no doubt that those consumers who are more vulnerable due to age, physical or mental health problems, or simply due to a lack of proper information, must be protected more carefully.
I therefore cast my vote in favour of the text by my colleague Mrs Perez because I agree that the creation of a strategy for consumer rights
The so-called most vulnerable contribute not only to their social inclusion but also to ensuring a safer, fairer and more competitive single market.
Mr President, the report by our colleague Mr Perez, to which we have given our favourable vote, deals with the need to consider the development of a
strategy aimed at protecting the rights of the most vulnerable consumers, in view of the strategy that the European Commission and the Member States will be called upon to develop in this regard.
The conditions of consumer vulnerability arise from causes of different nature and potentially can affect everyone.

For this reason, it is necessary to provide protection for this category alongside the general protection of consumers, and to develop a targeted strategy in this regard that, while taking into account the complex nature of the problem, avoids

on the one hand, the formulation of static and rigid definitions that are unable to consider all the facets of the issue and the different possible forms of vulnerability, and on the other hand, prevent the creation of new types of discrimination.
It is therefore necessary to arrive at the definition of specific and targeted protective measures.

Thank you, Mr. President. The management of bluefin tuna fishing has a long, rather complex history, dating back to the 1990s, and is currently probably the most strictly regulated by the European Union.
Despite substantial investments in monitoring having led to greater compliance with regulations, there are still concerns about the problem of overfishing.
I therefore expressed my support for the Romeva i Rueda report, which proposes a reduction in the allowable catch rate, greater control, and the strengthening of measures to reduce capacity.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the relations between the European Union and China clearly show situations of imbalance at a commercial level.
It is therefore incumbent upon European institutions to strive to help European businesses emerge from the crisis and succeed in making access to international markets more equitable.
I therefore expressed my support for this report, particularly sharing the rapporteur's concerns about the application of the principle of reciprocity to the
relations between the European Union and China to allow fair competition in international markets and the demand for greater protection of intellectual property rights.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, there is still a long way to go, but today's can be an important step towards finally introducing and implementing a financial transaction tax.
I understand the prudence, caution, and need for gradualism expressed by Commissioner ≈†emeta, as well as the technical problems rightly discussed by Minister Vestager.

But precisely for this reason, I hope that Parliament will express a clear political will, with a large majority, to provide impetus and drive to the necessary initiatives to address the problems that still remain unresolved, especially at the Council level.
We all want to carefully assess the impact of this tax, but it is not right to stir up unfounded fears, which can also lead to contradictory and counterproductive choices.
I am referring, for example, to the logic behind the proposal for exemptions.
If you are concerned about reducing the impact of the tax, then it is important to have a tax base as broad as possible, with a low rate, and not to try to extend exemptions indefinitely.

For those concerned about the impact on small investors, I would like to remind them of the progressive nature of the tax, which means that those who carry out more transactions are taxed more heavily.
transactions and it is clear that the competent authorities will in any case have to ensure that attempts are not made to pass on any costs to customers and end-users.
I therefore hope that Parliament will vote in favour of this tax by a large majority.

Mr President, honourable Members, since 1990, the European Union has been providing economic aid in the form of grants, loans or a combination of both to countries experiencing short-term balance of payments difficulties through the instrument of macro-financial assistance.
The rather long timeframes, added to the difficulties revealed by the decision-making criteria used so far, have made it necessary to formulate some changes to the regulations.

I therefore welcome the proposal introduced in the new regulation, which aims to make the evaluation criteria faster and more effective, and to agree on clearer rules and conditions for the provision of macro-financial assistance.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, there are approximately one hundred million European citizens involved in various voluntary activities.

From major sporting events to cultural events, the role played by volunteers is crucial, and we must not overlook the work of those people who rush to provide help and solidarity in the event of serious natural or environmental disasters.
Volunteering constitutes one of the broadest expressions of active citizenship and a crucial activity for the development of democratic values and equality within the European Union.
For this reason, I advocate for the development of high-quality volunteering, both national and cross-border, and the removal of the existing obstacles.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, from the communications sector to finance, transport, energy, culture and health, the role played by technology is becoming increasingly relevant.
The increasing use of the Internet and digital media makes the problem of cybersecurity one of the priorities on the European agenda.

Information and communication technologies can indeed promote economic and social development only if the existing regulations guarantee user security with regard to data privacy and intellectual property rights.
For this reason, only full international cooperation involving member states, institutions, and industry can create a robust system capable of implementing effective measures to ensure cybersecurity.
Madam President, thanks to the Commissioner, you have said very important and widely shared things.
I find it truly, as he said, shocking that we have each lived in our own country with the numbers and figures that we heard earlier from our colleague Oconi.
But it is equally evident that this scandal has really highlighted the need for a careful evaluation of the European legislation currently in force on medical devices.

Unfortunately, this fraud has highlighted the shortcomings we have discussed in this courtroom, which the Commissioner has so well represented, so I would not like to dwell on this aspect in the short time available to me.
I believe it is important to put everything in place so that we can offer the best to our citizens.
But I believe that this scandal, which has taught us so much, could also be a point to take a further step forward and I agree with what the colleague said before.

The communication made to patients is really poor, it always only emphasizes the positive aspect, it says that there is a kind of eternal youth, of promised beauty, there are no prostheses that are absolutely risk-free.

I believe that this awareness, especially when it comes to pure cosmetic surgery, must be communicated to people, to girls, because we know that there are very young girls who are approaching this type of procedure.
I see that you are absent with conviction and so I urge you, let's really get to work, time is short, we should have already done it yesterday.
Mr President, honourable Members, the Council regulation on the multiannual plan for the stock of herring was adopted before the Treaty came into force, and therefore alignment was necessary.

This regulation, the first in the fisheries sector to be aligned with the treaty, is therefore of considerable importance, as the solution adopted in this case could influence the decision-making procedure applicable to other multiannual plans.
For this reason I cast my vote in favour.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, from Seveso to Bhopal to Toulouse, there have been numerous environmental disasters in Europe in recent years that have put the health of European citizens at risk.

The text by my colleague Ader concerns the revision of the Services Directive or two, which aims to mitigate the effects of those incidents involving significant quantities of dangerous and highly polluting substances released into the environment.

The revised regulations that will come into effect from June 2020 are aimed at protecting the environment and, above all, at limiting tragic consequences for citizens' health, and therefore I cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, I too would like to thank Mr Stevenson for the excellent work and approach he has given to this report, which essentially addresses the two main issues.

This is not just about a simple herring management plan, it is essentially about ensuring a future for fishermen in some respects and planning in the sea to ensure that it has its own protections over several years.
But the key point of this report is and remains the issue of delegated acts.

I believe that the Council must accept the approach given by the Lisbon Treaty and I also think that the time has come for Parliament, in some way, with a perhaps more authoritative voice than that of the European Parliament,
whether it is a debate within the Committee on Fisheries or a debate on a report concerning hake, have the courage to take a very clear and strong position on the issue of delegated acts.
We demand the right for these matters to be handled through the ordinary procedure.

So perfectly that the issue also involves, in addition to many other sectors of fishing, which will incidentally worsen with the ongoing reform, but it concerns issues related to agriculture and other topics.
The essential point is to respect the will of Parliament.
In drafting this report, no account was taken of the parties directly concerned, the road haulage companies.
In Italy, ninety-one percent of freight transport is carried out by road.
Their rights will be ignored if this report is approved in its current form.
In many committees of this Parliament, we work daily to reduce the financial and administrative burden on our businesses, but reports like these undermine our efforts.
all our efforts, because they will suffocate companies themselves with new bureaucratic burdens, with ruinous economic losses and with new forms of unfair competition.

It would have taken very little to achieve a balanced report, one that did not forget the right to survival of our companies in a very difficult economic period, but a dialogue of this kind was not possible.

On the contrary, the report deliberately ignored even previous legislative acts of the European Union, such as the 2002 directive on working time, and even ignored European Commission documents that recognized the dangers of practices like retrofitting, which is instead being proposed again in this report.
The document we will vote on tomorrow, colleagues, will ask you to forget the positive achievements made in recent years, and once again it will be European companies that will foot the bill.

Just to say, Mr. President, that ACTA was a very serious political mistake, let's leave aside the legal one, it has determined a reaction in the world of immense proportions and this is enough to say that it is a political mistake.
Why the benches?
because it raised the suspicion that access to the web, which is a major modern revolution, would actually be closed off.
And why is that?
because he made the mistake of lumping together counterfeiting and piracy, which are two distinctly different phenomena.
The way to combat counterfeiting has nothing to do with copyright.
And then there was another mistake that excluded Parliament from an important activity it has been carrying out for some time, which is to create a new copyright.

old copyright that existed before the web. So, the point is that we need to work on copyright and set aside ACTA, which is an obstacle, and reject it and exclude it, because it is an obstacle to our work.

Fortunately, after months and years of hesitation, the Commission has brought two important measures - orphan works and the upcoming one on copyright management companies - to the attention of Parliament.
This is the advantage. We work on this by reflecting with our brains and not just with our emotions, but without having any cards up our sleeves.
Mr President, simply to add my voice to the praise that this report has received in the House regarding the need to strengthen the capacity of the European Union
to be a place where it is possible to invest, produce and manufacture in line with our vision of an inclusive, socially and environmentally sustainable economy.

So I believe that some of the guidelines here are very useful in this measure, others can be added and I think it is important to gather this information, to work increasingly to ensure that the attractiveness is.
the consequence of territorial policies, of territorial marketing, of openness, is that the territory proposes a productive and industrial vocation.

manufacturing and service companies that, emerging from the territory, respect all environmental and European political compatibilities that go in this direction, from the territory and from Europe a voice that is attractive for investments and growth.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, when we talk about sensitive issues such as the authorisation of products and substances for use in organic production, we are talking about the protection of the health of European citizens.

It is important to meet consumer expectations regarding the quality of organic products circulating in European markets, and it is also important to ensure proper implementation of Community legislation by the authorities, bodies, and operators concerned.
For this reason, I cast my vote in favor of my colleague's text.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, starting with the initial comments on the Council, the phase of the reductive reading has now begun, and this is wrong because important steps forward have been made.
Consider, for example, the breaking of destructive ties between banks and public debt, the weak plan for employment and work.

The spirit of revival and a renewed path of political unity seems to be returning to the European institutions, after so much slowness and torpor, and a desire for real progress towards greater integration.
Yesterday we saw strong unity between Parliament and the Commission on this.

I am not talking about winners and losers, but it is undeniable that there has been a new institutional and political vitality compared to the past diarchy, which was the negation, the very antithesis of the community spirit.
There has been an initiative and activism from multiple countries, not to create new exclusive axes, but to build a common consensus that respects all member states.
This is the path of the political goal of unity, without which any banking, fiscal, and monetary union will be completely insufficient.
On June 20, with the Council's decision to give member states the option to reintroduce border controls, a new Europe was born, a Europe that was courageous in fulfilling the desire of...
greater security for its citizens, finally inspired by a more mature interpretation of the concept of solidarity, which is reduced to the defense of the rights of its peoples above all else.

To President Schulz, even though he is not present, I say that this historic decision does not represent an interinstitutional incident, but rather respect for the will of the citizens and not that of the Euro bureaucracy that for years has pretended not to understand what is really happening outside the glass palace.
No imaginary influx of illegal immigrants, Mr. President Schulz, but an increase in illegal immigrants, measured by Frontex, of thirty-five percent in two thousand eleven.

My only regret is that the scenes of political sterility that unfolded in this Chamber during the last plenary session took time away from a more useful and constructive activity: questioning why it was not we who defended the interests of our citizens, but rather the Member States.

If Parliament does not find its soul and the courage to go against the populist approach and the sterile platitudes on which it has been floundering for too long, it will continue to be a follower rather than a leader in the construction of the European project.
Mr President, I wish to draw the attention of this House to the fact that yesterday was...
officially announced that the Higgs boson has been measured and concretely identified.
the particle that gives mass to all the others and their existence, and this happened on European soil.
Science gives life to our land and civilization and well-being and for a moment we can aspire to return to being a world science capital.
Utopia is the characteristic of man who invents a utopia and wants to realize it, and it is for science and for this wonderful ambition of man that today a person
A blind person who has no eyes can see with their hands or read a book with their ears, and a young South African boy who has no legs can run in the Olympics in a speed competition.
Well, Europe must be the homeland of science. This great event that will open new frontiers to knowledge must be fully supported by Europe.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, all too often within the European Union, victims of crime do not report incidents due to fear or lack of trust in the institutions.
The text voted on today aims to strengthen the rights of crime victims and ensure they receive the same level of protection, assistance, and access to justice across all countries.
all EU countries, paying particular attention to those victims who are at a high risk of suffering further prejudice or intimidation during the criminal proceedings.

Of particular importance is therefore the recognition of victim status not only for those who have suffered prejudice as a result of a crime, but also for family members and the deceased as a result of the crime.
On September 11, the Catalan people demonstrated peacefully in Barcelona.
One million people have called for Catalonia's independence from Spain.
On October 15 last year, British Prime Minister Cameron signed the agreement to allow the referendum for Scotland's independence from London.
In Veneto, my region, in recent weeks thousands of people have signed to hold a referendum for the independence of Veneto from Italy.
Yesterday in Veneto, in Lombardy and in all the northern regions, hundreds of thousands of people signed to have more autonomy from Rome.
But also in Flanders, in the Basque Country, citizens are clamoring for autonomy and independence from nation-states.
What does President Schulz say?
It requires a courageous commitment to clearly say no to all separatist tendencies.
His deputy Vidal Cuadras, even worse, has called for the use of force against Catalan citizens.
Their statements are a most serious act, contrary to the principles of the democracy that we preach here and that we should defend.
I tell them that it will be the people who will write the future of the new Europe, not the bureaucrats in Brussels.
The path is already mapped out.
The austerity policy adopted to overcome the economic crisis has not yielded the expected results.
As was emphasized in the report by my colleague Lavia, only by investing more selectively and supporting the ideal of a European budget aimed at
by supporting growth and employment, it will be possible to rebalance the economy of the member states, thereby improving the situation of European citizens.
For this reason, I therefore cast my vote in favor.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the social and economic context in which the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 is being discussed is rather problematic.

With member states engaged in making fiscal adjustments to their national budgets to redress public finances, the European Union is seen in some cases as an entity that increases the financial burden on taxpayers.

For this reason, in order to truly emerge from the crisis and guarantee a better future for young Europeans, it will be of fundamental importance to support greater and more concrete investments in the sectors of training and development.
This is the charter of an institution. The budget reveals what it is, what it does, and above all, what it wants to do in the future.

We are faced with a crucial choice between a budget of survival, of dragging things along, perhaps a little less for everyone, or a budget of courage, of selective choices, of investments in employment, innovation, and young people, that is, for the future of the European Union and its vocation for development.

Everyone should understand that, as my colleague Kalfin, among others, has said very clearly, Europe can do today what the states can no longer do for the economy, for regional development, for the territories, where social cohesion is established or the lives of the citizens we have spoken about are destroyed.
Europe's major decisions are now at risk of being stifled by the bureaucratic disputes within the Council, and not only between beneficiary countries and paying countries.

We say that it is a false problem because it is easy to demonstrate, with figures, with numbers, not with words, that for what has happened in the past, the contributing countries, sometimes more than others, benefit from the convergence of economies and growth.
The Council is currently working on putting figures next to the various headings.

The war of positions has begun, with declarations and statements from some states that view the budget as just another expense that can be cut without remorse, and perhaps even useful in bolstering anti-European sentiment, which is easy to stir up during times of economic crisis.
It is a wrong position that does not help that integration that we are trying to achieve in other areas.
Dear colleagues, our Europe is still incomplete and mutilated, as many of us have said.
We adopted a stability pact that was also meant to be a development pact, but we have become so stable that we are now in recession.
Here, let us at least take the opportunity of this budget, of this multi-year framework, to make choices in the right direction.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the lack of information and awareness about one's rights, coupled with the obstacles,
Language barriers and the non-recognition of diplomas and qualifications are the most common problems faced by EU citizens when they reside, study or work in another European Union country.
Unfortunately, there is still a lack of visibility of the notion of Union citizenship and its concrete benefits.
This is why I expressed my support for 2013 as the European Year of Citizens.

The primary objective is indeed to strengthen awareness of the rights associated with Union citizenship and to help citizens fully exercise their right to move and reside freely within the territories of the Member States.
Mr President, honourable colleagues, the proliferation of innovative financial instruments poses numerous challenges in terms of regulation, governance and monitoring their effectiveness.
In fact, it is necessary to find a fair balance between the objectives of transparency and control, as well as a sufficient level of effectiveness and speed of implementation.

The introduction of such instruments at the European level is, however, of great importance, as it represents a means by which the European Union, especially in times of crisis, can stimulate investment in the economy.
in a manner consistent with its own objectives, in a context where the continuous decrease in responses to the Community budget is juxtaposed with the constant growth of its political ambitions.
The Brussels I Regulation has undoubtedly been one of the most effective acts
of Union legislation, as it has outlined the foundations of a European judicial area, promoted and fostered legal certainty among European citizens.
The recast of this regulation addresses fundamental issues for the development of European justice, including the extension of the rules on the
on the jurisdiction of disputes with parties domiciled in third countries and agreements on the choice of jurisdiction.
I am convinced that the approval of the new regulation can ensure stronger consumer protection and greater legal certainty within the internal market, and for this reason I cast my vote in favour.

Commissioner, today you have called on Europe to take on a new task of coordinating industrial policies, and even the most staunch supporters of autonomy and private initiative are now calling for the exercise of this role.
Without greater Europeanization of national strategies, including in terms of employment protection, the current crisis cannot be overcome and there will be no recovery.
The car crisis is not just about overproduction capacity, it's about a dramatic loss of jobs.
But the crisis now seems structural and concerns the very fate of the car and the product, just as it does today.
We want to keep the car industry in Europe and we want to avoid dispersing the skills, the existing know-how, and the professional expertise.
We therefore call for the launch of a major restructuring and relaunch project, and for this to be done quickly, because the costs are proportional to the time taken.
Restructuring cannot be the result of fragmented national decisions or individual company actions alone.
At the very least, we must attempt to coordinate and guide this painful process at the community level, bringing the interested parties together through social dialogue.
producers, trade unions and individual country governments, providing support for research, innovation, human capital formation, retraining, and the necessary funds.
I know it will be a difficult task because the national interests of individual companies are not aligned.

But since the competitive clash underway in the European Union is very ambiguous and sometimes risks being unfair, I think that in the end it is in the interest of all countries to have effective community impetus and guidance to jointly face the increasingly aggressive global market.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, the energy crisis has cost and is costing an extremely high price to all employment, to thousands of precarious workers, but also stable and temporary workers, who are numerous in this sector.
The major steel groups are increasingly orienting themselves towards the Far East or the American continent, and this raises a major question about the direction of our development model.
I think Europe needs to rediscover the idea that a manufacturing system like ours needs solid basic production capable of supplying the European internal market.
We must therefore defend this sector and the role of a stable steel industry; we will support it, Commissioner, if we want to stop industrial decline.

I believe that we must also move away from a dualism that is not being discussed here tonight, but is often heard in debates about this sector, a dualism between environmental supporters and workers, which is wrong because it does not allow us to see a future perspective.
An industry that sees steel production as an integral part needs advanced production systems, concrete and balanced solutions that safeguard different interests and diverse needs.

Therefore, a strong planning approach is needed, including at the European level, that focuses on sustainability, which, in my opinion, we must not abandon, as it represents a genuine added value with which we want to compete in the world, supporting investments as has been said.

It has been said by many that new technologies, new processes, and the requalification of plants are necessary for a European economy that makes effective use of resources, including energy resources, indeed starting with energy resources, and also for the research of new and different materials.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, as we have mentioned in this Chamber, next December the United Nations Agency dedicated to communication and information technologies will meet in Dubai for the World Conference on International Communications.
The subject is the renegotiation of international telecommunications regulations.

We cannot forget and I am pleased with Commissioner Tajani's words about the work that has been done to date and which cannot be called into question, nor can we allow the authority of the European Union to be bypassed.

a supranational structure like the ITU, of which we know hundreds of states from all over the world are part, and many of which are known for a problem related to democracy, transparency, and freedom of expression.
So it is not wrong to believe that the pillars of the internet, namely freedom, participation, openness, and innovation, are in danger.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to protect the role of the Internet and the role that the Internet can play in relaunching economic growth, but not only that, also to ensure opportunities for everyone.
I therefore hope that the Commission will work towards ensuring that Europe in Dubai is united and speaks with one voice.

Many controversial proposals have been presented at the negotiating table of the World Conference on International Telecommunications, particularly those that envisage changes to Internet governance, which call into question net neutrality, with negative repercussions for consumers.
At risk, therefore, is the freedom of the Internet or, more precisely, the freedom of expression and data protection.
What some states have proposed would indeed allow a government to meddle not only in the communications of its own citizens but even in the data that passes through its networks.
The step from here to the limitation of freedom of expression to censorship is extremely short and therefore I believe it is in contradiction with the fundamental principles of the European Union.

Mr President, honourable colleagues, I have expressed my support for the text of my colleague, and in particular I agree with the rapporteur in emphasising the fundamental role played by national judges in the application of law within the Union.

I therefore consider it necessary to fully support the European Union's efforts to improve and coordinate training in the field of jurisdiction for judicial and administrative authorities for legal professionals.
All sector initiatives should also be intensified in order to fully realize the concept of a Union based on the rule of law.

Mr. President, Honorable Colleagues, in recent years the extraction of so-called unconventional hydrocarbons, including shale gas and oil, has led to an unprecedented transformation in global energy markets.
Europe, in order to cope with this situation and be less dependent on hydrocarbon imports, will therefore have to rely on its potential gas and shale reserves.
In this regard, some Member States have already authorized the exploration for shale gas and are preparing for the extraction phase if the discovery allows it.
In such a context, it becomes necessary to monitor the regulations concerning the extraction of shale gas within the borders of the Union so that the effects of its extraction are more effective.
extraction, undoubtedly valid from an economic standpoint, do not create environmental problems due to the possible release of harmful substances into the groundwater or the atmosphere.
Mr President, I believe that today's meeting should be an opportunity to discuss Kazakhstan objectively and the important agreement that the country is negotiating with the European Union.
Kazakhstan is a crucial country for the stability and strategic future of Central Asia and is an indisputable important economic and trade partner of the European Union.

This is a country that has already initiated a process of economic reforms and also a democratic process, but that still needs to make a great effort to bring these processes to a successful conclusion.

However, it is a country that, with this objective, persists in demonstrating its readiness for new and more robust reforms, and I believe that it is the task of the European Union to accompany these reforms.

For this reason, I am certain that the signing of this enhanced agreement will allow for progress, because its approval will strengthen an already solid and productive relationship and ensure ongoing assistance from the European Union.

I also remain convinced, and I believe this should have been even more emphasized in the report we will vote on tomorrow, that the improvement of progress on the path to democracy and human rights must be accompanied by a renewed and mutual commitment to open and constructive dialogue.

Our goal should not be to take a negative stance towards these and other countries in the face of the failure to immediately implement changes, our goal should be to support these countries' efforts to achieve the goal of respecting human rights principles as well.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, in thanking the rapporteurs for the reports we will be voting on tomorrow, just a brief point on the thrust, and I endorse what I have heard this evening as the unanimous voice of all my colleagues.
but I wanted to focus on artisanal fishing, on the Ferrera report, which I welcome and congratulate him on.
I wanted to say that with the past common fisheries policy, we have only contributed to increasing the gap between the institutions that regulate fishing and its real actors, namely the fishermen.

Unfortunately, up to now in Europe, the lack of a proper definition of artisanal fishing has penalized those who have always considered fishing as an activity linked to the traditions of their place, their seas, and their cuisine.

Thus grew the belief that the European Commission's approach was to standardize all fishing in Europe under large-scale industrial fishing, following only market logic and not listening to the concerns of thousands of fishermen who, for a couple of...

For decades, they have been operating according to rules related to the preservation of the ecosystem, with which I can only agree, but which have never preserved the work activities of the microeconomy of artisanal fishing.
This own-initiative report is a strong signal to the Commission and could result in practical measures to benefit the micro-economy of the fishing industry.
The report in fact highlights a number of advantages of allocating a minimum amount to small-scale fisheries from the European Fund.
Projects with integrated solutions that benefit the coastal community as a whole must be encouraged, and, Commissioner, it will also be essential to encourage young people's access to

We have discussed this sector several times in committee because, otherwise, not only will fishing die out, probably due to the depletion of the seas and fish stocks, but it will also likely die out because young people are no longer drawn to this sector.
This report is an opportunity to include training and incentive moments for young people who want to get closer to the sector.
The floor now goes to Mr Toia, two minutes. Like many colleagues today, I ask the Council that made this proposal, but what do you intend to do, gentlemen of Europe?
Do you want to minimize it, freeze it in the future?
But it is that same Europe that then wants to relaunch with the Van Rompuy document on integration.
But with what consistency, I wonder, does Van Rompuy manage these two dossiers?

And what consistency can citizens find between the decisions of July, employment and growth, the grand appeals to hope and the future in the European Union that we also hear from the Council, and this violent fall, then, in the name of realism, into a perspective of minimal survival.
How will it be possible, with these figures and these cuts, to turn the much-vaunted major reforms of cohesion and the CAP into concrete actions and active policies?
These are sincere questions, we would like a clear, honest answer, because there are signs here of an institutional schizophrenia that Parliament no longer accepts, that citizens no longer accept.
Parliament wants consistency, it wants credibility.

The first criticism is that at the budget level, we have nothing but growth and investment; we are at the 2008 budget. It must be acknowledged, however, that with regard to heading one, the van Rompuy proposal overturns the scandalous Cypriot proposal.
It is true that here the role of the budget as an irreplaceable driver of growth in certain sectors is recognized, in addition to national budgets.

But growth and innovation, let it be clear, must not come at the expense of other sectors, which are also part of growth and jobs, such as cohesion policy, and also, dear gentlemen, such as agricultural policy, which has increased employment and is increasingly oriented towards innovation and the protection of the territory.
Growing Jobs is about culture, training, transnational networks, the CEF and also solidarity and international development, human rights in the world and our contribution to the Millennium Goal.

Unfortunately, what we are faced with is the usual spectacle of the Council: no vision, no guidance, a Tower of Babel of national interests, opposed and in competition with one another, an inextricable tangle of vetoes, expectations, and general dissatisfaction.
And Europe, unfortunately, is the big absentee.
Mr. President, finning is an environmentally unacceptable practice, as it threatens the sustainability of certain shark species from those

This is problematic on a social and economic level, as it involves the waste of a food product with commercial value, and from an ethical standpoint, as it demonstrates a complete lack of respect for animal life.

Although this practice has been prohibited since 2003 in European waters and for the European fleet, the Commission has decided to present a proposal aimed at eliminating the exemption to the ban on removing shark fins on board Union fishing vessels.

This proposal, in addition to further ensuring that sharks receive the protection they need, will thus enable the European Union to actively contribute to the global effort underway to eradicate the cruel practice of shark finning in other parts of the world as well.
